Add-Ons are very much down to personal risk tolerance and account / money management, so the basic rules will apply as to how many trades you have open and what percentage of your account is at risk.   
  
To date I have yet to see a successful EA with supporting evidence of a trade explorer, so until that happens, I am staying with manual trading - most of the folks posting trade explorers accounts on FF run well for a while and then seem to blow up, so not sure if these are serious long term investors or just folks playing with high risk strategies - beware.  
  
Start with reading this post and the referenced posts and you should be on the right track.  
  
Following on from the outstanding success of Eelfranz ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f647-200d-2642-fe0f.png?v=15.1)\- Big E's Trading Made Simple forum, and X-Man's Super Simple System - several traders have requested a new thread be set up for TMS trading with Day Charts only.  
  
I do update this post with general rules and tweaks as I see them for the day charts and will also bring in comments from other members. I'll check in from time to time and post training charts and trade summaries and I will nuke non-compliant posts - my privilege – I started the thread ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1). I will also add any new insights / clarifications / techniques in this post as well as references to applicable post #s, so Post #1 may well become seriously long winded. If you want to reference a post from a member, please include the post # and member name.  
  
Once you have read this post, read through the trading charts that run through entries and add-ons and then you can jump to Post 1081 which us where I start trading with the revisions to the template. All of the indicators that you need are in this post as attachments or are described / referenced and are part of the standard MT4 indicators, such as MA and Bill Williams.  
  
Please take the time and effort to read this post carefully and the referenced post - take notes, read again and run backtesting and then ask questions. We all love helping newbies, but only if you put some effort into your trading. We were all newbies once.  
  
The overriding rule is that this forum is for Day Charts only and is based upon the time trusted and proven TMS methodologies as adapted and introduced by Big E (Rest in Peace), so let’s keep to the TMS spirit and keep Big E’s memory and his dream alive. Trade set ups are welcome as well as active trades or trade summaries / rationales for entering / exiting. We also want to see the ooopsies – and the lessons learned from the pain and suffering incurred!

**_Trade Set-ups and Commentaries:_**  
Here's a suggestion for posting trade set-ups / commentaries from fxjourney in Post #17:  
1\. Entry setups and brief explanation as to why you think the setup looks good (not only technical set up reasons but also risk/reward)  
2\. Trade Stop Loss management  
3\. Effective exit strategy  
  
My current commitments do not allow me to trade lower timeframes and I have moved to the Day Charts. My Broker is IBFX and my new day candle starts at 4pm PST. I typically place trades between 8pm and 10pm PST (which is the 2nd H4 candle of the day). These will either be pending trades with sell stop or buy stop levels set for Fractal Breaks or potential TDI Crossovers – especially moves from below 32 or from above 68. Price Action is the Key, so watch for the momentum to support the signals. Look left and pick up on support and resistance levels / Fractals.  
  
When using the RSI(10), I am looking at 25 as OverSold and 75 as OverBought - as the RSI(10) crosses the 50, there is usually a trade entry opportunity once you confirm with PA - Watch the value in the Data Window as this will overload the indicators on the screen. Any tine RSI is hovering around the 50 then you are looking at consolidation, so wait for Fractal Breaks / S/R level breaks.  
  
**_Multiple Time Frame Analysis:_**  
As far as MTFA– I do check the week for trend direction and always check out what the the 200ema is doing - this is the favourite institution ema and acts as a very dynamic S/R region - I may rarely look at lower timeframes - if the day looks good, I will enter.  
  
_**Supply and Demand Levels:**_  
I hve been tidying up the charts and going back to basics, so the [II_SupDem.ex4](http://www.forexfactory.com/attachment.php?attachmentid=1105034&stc=1&d=1420986551) indicaor is optional to get you thinking about Supply and Demand / S/R levels.  
  
Break outs / Reversals usually coincide with the APB changing colour for a good reversal signal. Basic Rule here is to sell as the candles leave a Supply Zone heading South and Buy as the PA leaves a Demand Zone heading North. If price blows through a Zone, this just means that the Trend has held and will usually give you a pause before bouncing and continuing.  
  
With the Day charts this involves patience and avoiding the need to enter a trade for a few pips. If you study some of the available material - either in FF on the threads, or in the numerous ebooks that circulate with the hope of hooking you for a subscription service, then you will see there is no real fixed rule for this type of entry - it all comes down to your trading style and your trading plans.  
  
My preference is to let the candle close and then follow the momentum of the PA. From the charts that I am now posting, you will see that the 100ema and 200ema will often act as a floating S/R - be aware of this when trading with set-ups heading towards these emas, especially when your entry point is within 100 pips and especially when 100 and 200 are running horizontal together - check out this post - [http://www.forexfactory.com/showthre...97#post5779197](http://www.forexfactory.com/showthread.php?p=5779197#post5779197)  
  
One very well written article that I have seen, talked to how momentum was perceived / interpreted. The focus was on the second half of the candle's life as this demonstrates the support and demand for the current PA. You can have a great bull push in the first half of the candle with new highs being set, only for the bears to take over which will leave you with a pull back candle with a large wick - this negates any momentum that was achieved earlier in the day. This often occurs around S/R levels and folks get faked out by the initial strength of the candle, only to watch it fall away at the end of the day.  
  
If, however, the bear push continues into the latter part of the day, then you have a strong momentum candle and if this succeeds in breaking the S/R, then look for continued momentum to drive the PA.  
  
This supports the Big E message that not all TDI crosses are not created equal and you still have to be on your game with the forex basics.  
  
**_Trade Entries:_**  
Is there such a thing as a perfect set up? My ideal scenario would be the following for long entries for reversals (and they do happen):  
  
APB/HA closes and changes colour  
PA moves with some strength - this means its day ATR(1) is at 75% or higher of the ATR(7) - this should also be stressed that the candle body needs to be strong - larger body than wicks.  
RSI moving above 51 / breaking through the 50 with strong momentum  
TDI cross within the last 1 or 2 candles and moving up from the 32 region  
Day chart showing recent trading range of swings (next Supply / Demand Zones 150 + pips away)  
  
For short entries:  
APB colour change to red  
PA moves with ATR(1) at 75% or higher of ATR(7)  
RSI moving below 49  
TDI cross within the last 1 or 2 candles and moving down from the 68 region  
  
  
Generally, trading into the 200ema is bad news -a strong enough PA will push through the 200ema and continue on its way. If the 200ema is dead flat, PA will very likely follow it and consolidate - wait for the breakout.

**_Trade Exits:_**  
For those of you that followed Big E - his trading style was structured to preserve pips, so he would exit on TDI flattening / hooks / pull backs and then look for re-entry positions. Also, Big E was not trading day charts - he did trade H4 and lower timeframes for London / NY openings. I have a flexible approach to exits and may change in accordance with S/R or general momentum. If you exit early, then look for re-entry possibilities on the H4.  
  
With regards to any indicator that has an Overbought / Oversold region - once these indicators are in the OB / OS regions, they cease to be reliable as trends can continue to add hundreds of pips after these regions have been entered - watch for candle sizes / S/R levels and further breakouts - very few indicators will help you here - Price Action will always be king!  
  
**_SL and TP levels:_**  
From the TMS thread - dcginc posted several posts on setting up SL and TP levels using the ATR(7) and I have tweaked this to match my approach.  
  
I now run with 3 entries per set-up and base my SL on the current ATR(7) - usually 1.5XATR(7) or the previous swing H/L / Fractal.  
  
TP1 for reversals is 1.5XATR(7) - this will mean SL levels are sometimes 200 + pips on the more volatile pairs.  
  
TP2 - options here are to set TP2 at 3XATR(7), OR, for TP2, you can always leave this open and manually manage the trade. My suggestion is to start out wit the fixed  
  
TP3 - no fixed level - run with manually adjusting SL levels  
  
Experiment with TP1 and TP2, see how it works, modify as necessary, but don't allow the greed glands to take over your trading plan ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f911.png?v=15.1)  
  
Once TP1 is hit, move TP2 and TP3 to B/E and then manage to your trading plan.  
  
**_Trade Management:_**  
There are several posts on manual trade management such as: 164 / 204 / 246. I will always let TP1 close out, so for my trade management, this is for TP2 and add-ons. For trend runs, I manually move my SL up to the previous but one (2 candles previous) candle L for longs (wick not body), H for shorts.  
  
As trend runs approach major S/L levels, the 200EMA / Big Round Numbers / 32/68 on TDI, 25/75 on RSi(10), be aware the trade can stall or bounce against you, so consider a manual exit and then re-enter if the S/R is broken and the move continues.  
Typically, the TDI will flatten out in the Overbought (>68) and Oversold (<32) regions and that the TDI will start to give exit signals on trade slow downs and stalls.  
  
As the candles start to shorten, this is the signal that momentum is fading. The end results are one of three options - congestion / ranging market, trend stall followed by reversal, trend stall followed by continuation (look for add-on possibilities on a new fractal break).  
  
Other possibilities include running with TS set to account for your ATR(7) - currently suggesting that the TS is not less than ATR(7) but then this depends what you are willing to sacrifice from your hard earned pips. Remember, it's not how much you make, but how much you keep!  
  
**_Money Management:_**  
Leonaforex made a great comment in Post # 295  
For my trades, I trade 3% of my account at any time, until 3 trades in a row are winners.  
I then increase to 4.5% of my account. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f911.png?v=15.1)  
One loss reverts to 3%.  
Two losses reverts to 1.5%.  
Three or more go to 1% of account and stay there until you figure out what you were missing. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f615.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/2753.png?v=15.1)  
Once you have achieved 2 wins in row again, go to 3% of your account.  
  
Again - before going live with this, run the backtests for the trade methodology and then plug in different money management approaches and see how the drawdowns affect your account and how quickly you recover. Many folks use a fixed 2% max and this is pretty safe.  
  
Here is something that I read on another thread:  
  
You should classify any contemplated trade into one of the following five categories before putting on a position:  
**a.** Entrance into congestion  
**b.** A trade within a congestion  
**c.** A breakout from a congestion area  
**d.** A trend run  
**e.** Trend reversal  
  
The trader will have difficulty in formulating a successful and intelligent risk/reward (entry/exit) plan unless the trade is properly categorized before the trade is taken. The risk/reward parameters are different for each of the five types of trades.   
  
**_Candle Patterns:_**  
Watch for candle reversal patterns - in the attachments.  
  
**_Candlesticks vs APB vs HA - see Post #305_**  
With regards to candles - my preference is for traditional good old fashioned style candlestick charts- however, Heikin Ashi or Synergy APB (Average Price Bars) have also worked well and continue to do so on the original TMS and X-Man's threads. The APB /HA appproach centers around a colour change on the day chart - When a colour change occurs, go look at it - review the PA and if it has momentum then it has a reasonable probability of succeeding - PA always takes priority in the decision making process.  
  
With day charts, it's not like you are rushed into a trading decision, so you have time to verify PA with either the APB and Candlesticks/price bars. Using candlesticks will of course require some understanding of candles and especially reversal patterns. Again, as with so many other aspects of forex - pick what works for you and run with it - you must be comfortable with your chart settings and not become one of the sheeple trying to make something alien work just because other are doing it.  
  
For general reading on TMS and trading strategies – look to the following members (most are from the original TMS Thread and although these are not necessarily day chart traders, their approaches and methodologies are sound and will translate to any timeframe):  
Eelfranz / dcginc / X-Man / Phx62 / Emmanuel7788 / Vantage / Dean / Lawgirl – apologies to those whom I have missed – nothing intentional, just attribute it to lost brain cells over the years.  
  
As far as trading opportunities, you will probably see each pair have one good set up per week and there are usually several high probability trade set ups each week across all the pairs – if the market is ranging – leave it alone and come back another day. The day charts will easily bring you pips and with less stress and less false signals. My experience has been between 800 to 1200 pips per month since July which is when I picked up on TMS. This can be achieved on a single currency pair, or over multiple pairs.  
  
**_Abbreviations used in posts_**  
  
TP1 - Take Profit for Entry #1  
TP2 - Take Profit for Entry #2  
TP3 - Take Profit for Entry # 3  
AOC - Add-On Candle  
BE - Break Even  
S/R - Support / Resistance  
S/D - Supply / Demand  
DD - Drawdown  
  
  
Install the indicators into your MT4 platform - folder name "experts" and then sub folder name "indicators"  
  
  
_**Indicators for Chart (Day)**_  
Synergy_APB_[C]  
ATR Pips UL Corner – color to none - periods 1 – multiplier 1 - this will give you the ATR for a single candle  
ATR Pips UL Corner – color to none - periods 7 – multiplier 1 (read dcginc posts for using this and setting SL and TP)  
EMA 200 – blue dotted – Price Typical  
EMA 100 – aqua dotted – Price Typical  
Fractals (Bill Williams)  
Supply and Demand indicator II_SupDem - optional  
  
**_Indicator Window 1_**  
TMSTDI Watchdog – all settings at defaults – Set the alarms that you do not want to false and adjust the font sizes accordingly for your set-up. Colors are personal preference for the TDI lines - I do not use the "Bollinger" lines, so I stick with TSL / RSI and MBL  
Overlay the RSI set to 10 with no color – just a personal preference – higher probability trades when RSI(10) is above 51 for longs and below 49 for shorts. Again – another one for the Data Window.

  * [![](https://assets.faireconomy.media/nfs/customavatars/thumbs/medium/avatar176273_2.gif) Britpip7](britpip7)

This is for aud/usd from the past 72 days.  
  
In summary - all trades taken at TDI cross - typically after 1st candle has closed after crossing the 5ema - this is the set up candle and establishes the entry point - top or bottom of the candle wick depending on long or short entry.  
  
For this chart there are 6 entry points over a time period of 72 candles / days - this is about training yourself to see the entries and the associated patterns. As has been pointed out on other threads, anyone can pick winners from an old chart, so look for the patterns / set-ups for entry points. Some trades may take 5 days or more to develop, so extreme patience is required.  
  
Trust the 2XATR(7) for your SL for reversals, it has been proven to work many times over. For tighter ranging markets, drop to 1XATR(7) for TP1.  
  
Total pips if all entries were hit = 2,986  
  
Entry 1 - TP1 = 338, TP2 = 490  
Entry 2 - TP1 = 322, TP2 = 280 - this was a continuation trade / Fractal break / bounce  
Entry 3 - TP1 = 348, TP2 = 470  
Entry 4 - TP1 = 284, TP2 = 230  
Entry 5 - TP1 = 75, TP2 = 75 - first signs that pair is starting to range in narrower band  
Entry 6 - TP1 = 37, TP2 = 37 - market now ranging in a lower band - should now reduce TP1 to 1XATR(7) until range is broken

TDI is a primary indicator for TMS, however, support and resistance levels / fractals will give additional signals. I am trading with the TMS approach plus Fractals.  
  
The TDI in this instance would have crossed as the PA moved down and broke the Fractal Low, however, as the candle pulled back, the TDI RSI would have moved with the retrace and any TDI cross that would have been indicated would no longer exist.  
  
The trade was placed as a pending trade based on the Fractal Low being broken - not for all, but it works for me.

Thank you Britpip7 for starting this thread.  
  
As we are concentrating on the daily charts only here there is a good opportunity to announce potential setups quite far in advance of the entry signal, with lots of time to prepare for the trade, in most situations.  
  
There are plenty of currency pairs to trade - especially if one considers all the smaller currencies - so please announce any attractive looking possible entry set ups and we can then discuss and take action from there. I'm sure collectively we will cover all potential new setups across the whole currency market!  
  
The whole rationale behind Eelfranz's original system was simplicity so let's keep things simple else we will drive away members from this thread.   
  
In my posts here I will concentrate on three things:  
  
1\. Entry setups and brief explanation as to why I think the setup looks good (not only technical set up reasons but also risk/reward)  
2\. In trade stop loss management  
3\. Effective exit strategy  
  
For the above I will use Eelfranz's original rules as a start and may bring new ideas to the forum if I think there is value for others.   
  
I have never traded the daily chart and have a serious concern with leaving trades active over weekends (may result in big movements with no stop loss safety). However I guess that there will be trades on D1 that may remain in the market over weekends - this will be a new experience for me.  
  
Thank you.

_**Back Testing**_  
  
Traditional back testing is nothing more than using the F12 key.  
  
Switch off the "Chart Shift" and "Auto Scroll" buttons.  
  
Delete the Fractals  
  
Add in Volume - just shows the Friday/Sunday transition points - any set ups that occur at Friday Close, I normally let Sunday close and then enter as the Monday candle starts to form.  
  
Hold your left arrow key down for a few seconds and then move to testing with the F12.  
  
The TDI indicator will show you the historical day end position - I have only ever used F12, although there are backtesting simulators in play - check out X-Man's thread.  
  
As you hit F12, take time to look at the chart and understand the patterns.  
  
If you are in the middle of a trend run, look for pauses for possible new entry positions / TDI bounce.  
  
If a reversal starts to develop, look at the candle strengths / relative positions to 5EMA and the TDI set up.  
  
If you see the candles have aleady pushed through the 200EMA and the 55EMA, a reversal signal may just be a minor re-trace / pause.  
  
If you see the 5EMA, 55EMA, 200EMA all heading in the same direction, look for entry positions in that direction.

This chart covers 100 candles / days.  
  
Using the hindsight forex trading methodology, I have selected 16 entries.  
  
Placing two trades per entry position, each rectangle entry would have generated over 100pips - the ellipse entries were closer to break even.  
  
Each vertical line is a possible entry point. Each entry point was picked using candlesticks on the main chart - without using the TDI - I added the TDI back in afterwards and the correlation is pretty strong - couple of marginals, but the lessons learned here, is that Price Action gives you the entry point - all the other indicators are basically confirmation (lagging) of what the PA did. You could also take from this is that using the TDI will give valid entries on the Day Chart!  
  
As a rough estimate, there were approx 4,000 pips here, so on average 1,000pips per month from a single currency.  
  
Another point of note, is that I am currently using a 100pip TS. The drawdowns on the initial trend would stop out each of the entry positions, so each entry position was a new trade, with no open positions. The drawdowns varied from 140pips to 260pips nearing the end of the run.  
  
A hindsight lessons learned here is that the ATR(7) was running between 100pips and 150pips. If you calculate your TS as a multiplier of the ATR(7), maybe you would have run these trades with a TS of more than 100pips and kept more trades open for longer. As you go to higher timeframes, your SL / TP / TS settings become higher to allow for the required breathing room - these should all be based off of ATR(7) and should never be lower than this value.  
  
Another option is to run your SL and TP1 @ 2XATR(7) with TP2 @ 4XATR(7) (per dcginc for reversals where the market is trending, not range bound). When TP1 is hit, move the SL on TP2 to BE and let it run / manually manage it.  
  
Look for the patterns in the candlesticks - these can become a leading indicator when they are understood.

**GUYS I HAVE A LIL RECOMMENDATION.****The starter of the thread uses IBFX** **and according to their server time, their new day starts 4pm PST which is the same as 12am GMT.  
For the sake of uniformity, i recommend that we all use broker whose time zone starts 4pm PST and 12am GMT  
Here are the advantages:  
  
_Uniformity_  
_We see the same set ups, two heads are better than one_  
_Newbies will catch up very fast  
Even the pros will benefit as their possibility of making errors will be reduced  
We make the pips together  
  
_If your broker uses a different time zone, you can open a demo account with IBFX and watch out for setups on IBFX platform but the actual live trades will be taken on your own brokers platform.  
I recomend that hence fort, any trade setup or example should be displayed from a broker whose new day starts 4pm PST (12 am GMT).  
Guys what do you think?  
Franklin

This is not my call but here are my views on this suggestion:  
  
This thread is about trading the daily chart with a very straight forward system. The best way for members of this thread to learn to trade this system is for Britpip7 and other successful traders to share their trading activities right here - through posting charts etc.  
  
The beauty of trading the daily chart is setups take a long while to form and so 'real time' is slow enough to capture and post here for all to see and learn from.  
  
Creating another live trading forum and taking that part away from this thread would be a mistake in my opinion. Most live trading chat rooms become a place of 'follow the leader' where one trader calls his/her trades and the rest follow blindly without learning what they are doing.  
  
My two cents....

Depending on how much volume there is on Sunday / Monday:  
  
A/U - possible break to the upside - Fractal Up break / TDI strong cross / TMS Osc green for day and week / RSI(10) above 50  
  
E/U - sitting on a strong support line for the past 12 days - something has to give at some point  
  
NZ/U - similar to A/U as usual  
  
GB/NZ - possible Fractal Low break - TDI has bounced / TMS OSC red for day and week / RSI(10) below 50 - If the Fractal Low break does not occur watch for reversal signals  
  
GB/J - similar to GB/NZ  
  
AU/CH - possible divergence PA to TDI - waiting for possible reversal  
  
The rest of the pairs are already into trend runs or are seriously ranging - so, worth watching the trending pairs for a pause / fractal break - some of these are getting into OB / OS areas so be careful with new entries - maybe go for smaller profit targets.  
  
My only open trade is E/NZ which has two trades running in parallel. TP1 is set for 270pips (originally set @ 2XATR(7) based on the candle values at the time of setting the trade), TP2 has not been set, so I am manually managing this. Currently I have a TS of 100 on both trades (100 pips protected on each) as that is all I am willing to surrender to the forex gods at this time. Bear in mind, that the current ATR(7) is 129 pips, so these trades could easily get stopped out when the market re-opens. All down to risk tolerance at this point.

CAD/CHF - no set up yet but based on divergence this pair is on my watch list for a short. I would be looking for at least 200 pips here.  
  
E/U - sitting on a strong support line for the past 12 days - something has to give at some point. No signal yet.  
  
NZ/U - similar to A/U as usual \- Agreed and similar look to AUD/CAD too.

GB/J - similar to GB/NZ \- I don't have the confidence yet to trade the 'Ninja Beast'!   
  
AU/CH - possible divergence PA to TDI - waiting for possible reversal \- sadly do not have this pair on the [Oanda](/brokers/oanda "View OANDA Broker Profile") MT4 platform!   
  
The rest of the pairs are already into trend runs or are seriously ranging - so, worth watching the trending pairs for a pause / fractal break - some of these are getting into OB / OS areas so be careful with new entries - maybe go for smaller profit targets. Agreed. In a number of cases entries were signalled 3 - 5 days ago and there have been decent moves as a result. Time for patience to wait for new and solid set ups.

Hi Andrea  
  
If it is a trend pause I will enter on the break and not wait for the candle to close.  
  
If it is a range set of fractals as in the eur/usd at the moment, I'll wait for a candle close. The eur/usd will be the subject of another post today.  
  
Pending trades are set to at least 10 pips above /below the fractals - if there is a significant Big Round Number, I will set 15 pips above below the BRN.

TDI Watchdog - the slope is showing you the angle of the TDI / associated cross / bounce.  
  
The theory is that the slope value for a cross should be above 4.5 - the values shown represent the TDI slope for the current candle and previous candle.  
  
The screenshot shows the watchdog settings.  
  
For a bounce the value shoul be at least 3.0.

Trade entered on 12/28 on Fractal Break - this was a later entry - could have taken the previous Fractal break (rectangle) which co-coincided with the TDI Bounce on 12/16, but missed it!  
  
Usual trade entry - two trades opened - SL & TP1 set to 2XATR(7), TP2 left open but with same SL. TS of 100 deployed.  
  
With any trend runs, a pause followed by a Fractal Break can be good for entries / add-ons. As a trend run gets longer, be aware that it could be nearing exhaustion, especially when it is running into previous S/R levels (see the ellipse). Watch for the TDI Down Zone line to continue with the trend. If the RSI Price Line breaks the TDI Down Zone, stay with it.  
  
Still watching for reversal signs, and previous patterns, so currently no indications that this will do anything but continue (famous last words!). Lower volumes today and no news, so basically prices are drifting. Not much Forex news on these pairs for the next few days, so other Euro Zone news will probably be the driving factor. As usual, following PA and not talking heads, etc.  
  
Currently 112pips of profit locked with the TS on both trades

In regards to the "overwriting", this often happens if you have used a template to set up that screen ... If you have, then on the pair you're on either:  
  
1\. Try changing your chart timeframe to match the templates timeframe, then change back  
2\. If that doesn't work, go into watchdog settings, set currency pair and timeframe to same as original template, then ok onto screen - watchdog will now show something in yellow writing in top right (e.g. EURUSD (H1) ). Go back into watchdog settings, change pair to "Current Symbol" and timeframe back to 0, ok out, should be correct now.  
  
If you've got the template from someone else, best to ditch using it and set up the screen new yourself. 

1 pip at a time ... if the entries are strong, the rest will follow ...

Having completed some relatively small volumes of backtesting, I thought I would offer this up to the group for comment.  
  
Currently I am entering with two trades for each entry.  
  
For trend reversals and trend continuations, my entry SL on the 1st trade and TP1 is set to 2XATR(7) with a TS of 100pips (This may need to opened up more where the ATR(7) > 100pips).  
  
For the 2nd trade, my SL is set to 2XATR(7) and my goal is to achieve a minimum of 4XATR(7) with the following process for managing the TP2 trade (using my current open trade on eur/nzd as the working example):  
  
1\. leave the entry SL in place until a minimum of 100pips profit is achieved and the trailing wick (H) has cleared the entry point.  
2\. At the end of each day, move the SL manually to the previous day's candle High (wick, not the candle body).  
3\. Keep doing this until a pullback finally takes you out (similar to the Dean Malone approach) - OR  
4\. When the candles show the trend is slowing / consolidation / possible reversal, consider switching to a TS based off of the ATR(7) - still under development, but initial backtesting shows a minimum of 1.25XATR(7) - all depends on which candle you use to calculate this - so this approach needs further forward testing in a demo account.  
  
From dcginc's approach, for reversal, he runs with the entry SL on the 1st trade and TP1 is set to 2XATR(7). TP2 is set to 4XATR(7) and when TP1 is hit, the TP2 SL is moved to BE. TP2 can then be managed or left to run. In ranging markets, he trades on lower timeframes and reduces the TP levels accordingly.  
  
The chart is showing TP1 running with 100pip SL and TP2 manually adjusted per point #2 above (they are both very close to each other, but hopefully gets the idea across).

Hi migmac  
  
If you go back and look at the chart you are referring to you will see that I have drawn yellow lines to show the divergence between price and both the TDI and Stochastics indicators.  
  
Look at price first (where I have drawn the yellow line) and notice that price has been trending down - hence the yellow line is downward sloping.   
  
Now look at both indicators at the same place when prices was going down. Again I have drawn yellow lines that show the indicators are sloping upwards - i.e. the indicators show divergence with price and this MAY mean that price will soon change direction and reverse.  
  
Here is a good website to learn more about divergence and other useful trading stuff:  
  
<http://www.trading-naked.com/Divergence.htm>

I just recently had my eyes open to the color change phenomenon, I'd all the while been bonded to M5 and M1 and my experience is that the XPMA indy does not repaint after a candle close so once it says blue it does not go back after 2 candles to say red. believe me I've tried a whole lot of indicators.  
  
Just today I went back and noticed that even on H1 TF, once XPMA changes color from blue to yellow (EMA5 shift 2) you could scalp a minimum of 7 pips in the direction of the color change that means after London and New york have had a good run, and the trend is exhausted, you can wait for a color change and pick some easy pips.  
  
So my simple suggestion is that you experiment it on the D1 charts, load the indicator, and back-test 6 months data and draw your conclusions.  
  
I've decided that the D1 charts is the way to go for me and I believe that the XPMA color change will be my litmus test to make me join a trend sure I'll get in late but hey someone said "experienced traders control risk inexperienced traders chase gain"  
Thanks to Britpip 7 I'll include fractal breaks for adding on positions plus we have a drag net of over 10 currency pairs to choose from.

BigE uses the EMA5 shift 2 as the setting basic setting for the TMS method.  
This I think replaces the 5 period price channel which you'd have to waith like 4 hours for price to close above or below the channel for an entry and exit signal.  
  
The EMA5 shift 2 also mirrors the TDI cross (i.e green crossing red) so when you see a candlestick closing above or beneath the EMA5 you should be seeing a TDI cross.  
  
Here are the settings for the EMA5 which comes with all MT4 platforms.  
Go to insert on your menu bar, select indicators, select trend and select moving averages.  
  
Thereafter just follow the example attached.  
Hope this helps.  
  
Edit   
  
The other EMA of note (my preference) is X-man's EMA60 this serves as an intermediate S&R level for H4 and D1 PA bounces off this level quite often on both time frames but you need to use what you are comfortable with.  
Britpip7 recommends EMA55 (I think) some others EMA100 so go ahead and play with all one at a time make your observations and stick to your choice just remember the connecting link is the TDI and EMA5 represents that so you may not be able to do away with that.

Please see my earlier post.  
No I do not enter as soon as the XPMA changes color, that is only the final confirmation.  
First TDI cross; then from where is the TDI cross coming, from 32 up or 68 down, from above 50 up or below 50 down?  
Then is the currency pair ranging or trending? This you can tell from the slope of the EMA5.  
The wonder of Forex is you can get all confirmations and still get faked out and stopped out so if all the considerations are met, my last line of defense would be the Xpma color change.  
The attachment is the settings for the XPMA's EMA5 on a D1 chart: note the color change however I'm not taking this trade because I don't like the slope of the EMA5 and I don't think the pair EURUSD is perfectly trending.  
Chew on this awhile.

Much depends on your trading style/plan.  
  
Big E would exit as the trade pulled back and re-enter if it resumed the direction.  
dcginc would set hard TP levels.  
Dean Malone uses the 5SMA band to exit.  
Many folks use the TDI flattening or reversing / hooking as an exit signal.  
Some folks have used the 5EMA as an exit indicator where they will close if a candle closes above / below it.  
  
I combine the hard TP levels with a TS and/or a manual exit strategy based on reversal patterns. Currently I am managing a trade with no TP set but by moving the SL every day - see my recent posts - I am also posting daily updates on any trades that I have open.  
  
Hope this is not too confusing, but this has to be be a personal preference based on your risk tolerance. How many pips are you willing to give back to the market?

The TDI cross refers to the crossing of the RSI Price Line (green) and Trade Signal Line (red) UPWARD or DOWNWARD.  
  
In fact there is an indicator by Xhaplod which gives an arrow signal on the main chart once green crosses red.  
  
The thread is "Indicators for TMS system"

Happy pipping.

Hi palinkasa  
  
Even though we trade the daily chart the 3rd candle of the new trend (change in colour) is still important. Eelfranz (the author of TMS system) explained that entering a trade on the 3rd candle, or later, might be too late and the market may reverse. In such situations he advised that it is better to leave alone trades signals that occur on the 3rd candle or later.  
  
In order for you to be comfortable with this rule it may be a good idea to do some back testing and see why he created this particular rule.

> 
> Disliked
> 
> We must watching 3rd candle in this system?It's daily chart,so that candle is not so important.

On a daily chart it's rare to have a TDI cross and have more than two candles but where it does happen it will keep you out of bad trades.  
  
There are other factors to consider when you may want to trade after two candles. For example if the preceding candles are really small and insignificant or if it's a bounce trade and moving in the direction of the existing trend.  
  
Personally I try to keep my trading as mechanical as possible so it's rare I will take a trade outside of my rules. Once you start bending your rules to make a trade fit you will get burned.

I am thoroughly enjoying trading TMS on the daily chart and my live account has already experienced quite a big jump since I started this approach about a week ago (in a thin market too!).  
  
I understand now why Eelfranz, Britpip7, X-man and others advocate trading the higher time frames (I am used to M15) and also why Eelfranz encouraged us to go purchase a wheelbarrow for all the cash we would make trading this way.  
  
I think Eelfranz's decision to use APB or HA candles rather than the default setup is brilliant and has been a big asset to my trading. I respect the fact that Britpip7 does not use them but they have been a big help for me.  
  
To date using this system I have placed 6 trades with 5 winners (3 still running) and one loss (AUD/JPY long: result -28pips).  
  
I want to share the losing trade here. I have given my two cents worth as to why I feel the 'rocket did not leave the launch pad'. Please feel free to offer your own critique too.  
  
In brief I now realise that there was not enough momentum on the weekly chart to keep the TDI cross on daily chart moving up. I put too much emphasis on the weekly stochastic and not enough on price and TDI slope which lead to a loss.

The key statement in the post was " A lot depends on the current candle continuing north - looking for this to break the next resistance (blue horiz line - previous Fractal Down)"  
  
PA did not continue, the candle did not close above previous Fractal (Resistance) and the 5EMA was never broken - result = no trade.  
  
Every reversal starts off going against the trend - but you must have confirmation and for trend reversals I wait for candles to close above the entry points. Even then, the next candle may revers, which is why you only trade the high probability entries.

Hi angelo5uk  
  
The APB / HA candles typically lead and warn of a trend change earlier than the TDI cross. So often, not always, you will see the candles change colour before the TDI crosses in the same direction as the candles of the new colour.  
  
If the TDI cross happens on candle 1 or 2 of the fresh colour candles (trend change ABP / HA candles) then it is valid.

Last night I've closed a bunch of trades (mostly xxx / CHF) for reasons I've explained in one of my previous posts.  
  
However, I've kept the charts of those pairs open, just to see where price would go. This way I could verify the validity of my exit strategy.

been doing a quick bit of back testing on the EU this morning. im confident with the TDI entries, i just find money management my problem from having a profitable trade turn against me (which does happen i know, part of the game), but mainly R:R.  
  
been testing 2xATR(7) for s/l but noticed some times stops would be 400pips+. However, from my back testing, the stops have never been taken out straight away, so what i have been doing is choosing either 2xATR(7) or previous High/low, which ever is smaller, then manually moving my SL to high of previous candle (short) or low of previous candle (long), with my TP1 at 2xATR(7)- i close half, keep rest in with SL @ 'x'+pips.  
  
out of the last 10 trades i have taken on EU from backtesting, i have had a success rate of 70% out of ONLY 10 trades- please dont take this for granted! (was just a quick back test.more testing required) with pips of 1063. i manually closed the trades which went against me from reading TDI and reversal candle strength. i did not enter Bounce trades, as i PERSONALLY, didnt find them worth the risk, when i did, i lost pips.  
  
i would love it if someone with more experience could give me some comments on my MM or share theirs. i have read about people using trailing stops, i will test that out on forward testing(demo).  
  
many thanks

And that gets you into the "overtrading" discussion.  
  
I will occassionally have more than one trade open and this is where I will invoke the ire of the MM gurus. I'll run with 5% risk per open trade,  
  
Typically I'll wait until an initial trade has hit a TP1 level before a new trade is opened if it meets the criteria.  
  
More typically I am looking to run with a single pair and look for re-entry / add-on positions, limiting the risk. - refer to some og the training charts for this approach.

Well I have lots of crosses on my platform :  
  
AUDPY AUDNZD AUDUSD  
GBPJPY GBPUSD NZDJPY  
NZDUSD USDCAD USDJPY  
  
I have been tinkering all weekend and making a few adjustments. For starters I have got rid of the stochastics. Eelfranz never used them as overbought/oversold but more as an indication of direction. This may work well on 4h & 1h times but I find them pretty useless on daily and too unreliable to base a trade decision on.  
  
Secondly I have gone back to basing take profit areas on ATR. This is something I used to use a year or so ago and worked well. Britpip reminded me how good this was and I only dropped it previously because I was following longer trends. I will still use previous support/resistance as the initial stop but this is a worst case scenario area. I would probably never let a trade go that far against me. First TP area will be 1xATR(20) and then move the trade to BE. Exits after that will be based on candle formation and how near price is pulling back to the 5EMA.   
  
Thirdly I have changed back to standard candles but have put HA candles in a separate window. I like the idea of HA candles and I see what Eelfranz was trying to get at but you do get a better sense of price action with standard candles. Interestingly I have noticed some discrepancies with HA candles. It's not unusual for HA candles to be indicating a short trade but the standard candle is obviously bullish and vice versa. Having both available gives a better picture. I will still probably follow the 2 candle rule though (although perhaps not so rigidly).  
  
Fourthly (phew) I have freshened up my platform and made it brighter. Was fed up looking at black, red & green ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f923.png?v=15.1)  
  
I will post some more on the TDI crosses later. It's Sunday afternoon here in the UK and it's time for some roast beef ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f61c.png?v=15.1)

I thought I would post something I learned from a seasoned trader long ago regarding money management -- it has held me in good standing, and stopped the blow out of my account MANY a time ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1)  
  
For my trades, I trade 3% of my account at any time, until 3 trades in a row are winners.  
I then increase to 4.5% of my account. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f911.png?v=15.1)  
One loss reverts to 3%.  
Two losses reverts to 1.5%.  
Three or more go to 1% of account and stay there until you figure out what you were missing. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f615.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/2753.png?v=15.1)  
Once you have achieved 2 wins in row again, go to 3% of your account.  
  
Hope this helps   
Leona

For my trades, I trade 3% of my account at any time, until 3 trades in a row are winners.  
I then increase to 4.5% of my account. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f911.png?v=15.1)  
One loss reverts to 3%.  
Two losses reverts to 1.5%.  
Three or more go to 1% of account and stay there until you figure out what you were missing. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f615.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/2753.png?v=15.1)  
Once you have achieved 2 wins in row again, go to 3% of your account.  
  
Hope this helps   
Leona[/quote]  
  
Very nicely explained - quite similar to my approach - worth adding as a concept to post # 1

As a brief overview - Heikin Ashi were created to average out the candlesticks so that the response time was slowed down and reduced false signals. The Synergy APB were deleveped to increase the responsiveness of HA for forex markets.   
  
[](http://www.forexfactory.com/attachment.php?attachmentid=868741&d=1325743772)[http://www.forexfactory.com/attachme...1&d=1325743772](http://www.forexfactory.com/attachment.php?attachmentid=868741&d=1325743772)  
  
As far as the mathematics behind the algorithms:  
  
Courtesy of Xaphod:  
  
The bar close value is calculated differently:  
  
Heikin Ashi:  
  
Code:  
haClose=(Open[pos]+High[pos]+Low[pos]+Close[pos])/4;  
Average price bars  
  
Code:  
haClose = (Open[i] + High[i] + Low[i] + Close[i]) / 4.0; haClose = (haClose + Close[i]) / 2.0;

AUDJPY - No trade on this one. Stuck in a tight range and the previous two crosses were losers.  
  
AUDNZD - Same story again but with flat price action and flat EMA and resistance at 1.3050  
  
AUDUSD - Initially I thought this looked quite good but now looking not so sure. Looks like a pull back to a trend line. If the candle was bigger and closed the other side of the EMA I would have had a go.  
  
GBPJPY - Technically this is a cross of the TDI but the previous long never went anywhere so I am going to call this more of a bounce trade. Price has pushed passed the resistance at 119.25 area, good size candle, right side of the EMA and with the trend.  
  
GBPUSD - Good TDI cross but price has reached this area three times before and failed. Trading in quite a large range but not enough to be traded on a daily time frame in my opinion.  
  
NZDJPY - Looks like exactly like the AUDJPY cross so no trade for same reasons.  
  
NZDUSD - Funnily enough looks like the same setup as AUDUSD. Possible pullback to a trendline so trade skipped for same reasons.  
  
USDCAD - Looks good. Good size candle, broke past the EMA. Need to watch for resistance at 1.0400.  
  
USDJPY - If you look at this with HA candles it looks like a really good move. But with standard candles it's obvious that the candle giving the signal is bearish and it's closed the wrong side of the EMA.  
  
So out of 9 crosses there are what I consider 2 good setups. AUD and NZD crosses seem to be consolidating somewhat. Maybe we will seem some bigger moves in the week from these.  
  
I will update the SL & TP for GBPJPY & USDCAD later when the market opens.

Here is something I recently read on another thread:  
  
You should classify any contemplated trade into one of the following five categories before putting on a position:   
**a.** Entrance into congestion   
**b.** A trade within a congestion   
**c.** A breakout from a congestion area   
**d.** A trend run   
**e.** Trend reversal   
  
The trader will have difficulty in formulating a successful and intelligent risk/reward (entry/exit) plan unless the trade is properly categorized before the trade is taken. The risk/reward parameters are different for each of the five types of trades.

Rule #1 - never attempt to catch a falling knife!  
  
This trade was perfectly set up with the 1st pause and then the 2nd pause and this is one of my favourite patterns to trade. This pattern repeats on many of the reversal trades, so if you miss the initial move, there is often a set-up for a second / third push. TDI will show a bounce, but once your tdi moves below 32, not much in the way of signals unless it breaks the lower band - hence my approach with TDI + Fractals.  
  
From my original screenshots on this, everything was saying short, so the trigger point was the Fractal Low at 1.6821.  
  
Apologies for the chart without TDI-Hist and Watchdog - laptop still broke and my backup system does not have all the indis loaded!

Hi angelo5uk  
  
I am not a 'guru' at the TMS method - but here are my 2 cents on your trade watch list:  
  
AUD/USD - major trend is long (weekly) with possible further movement up. Daily shows same direction. Some resistance at current levels (1.0300) that may hold things back a bit. Be careful.  
  
USD/CAD and AUD/JPY have similar situations on the weekly chart - no clear trend yet and so I would be wary of entering either of these trades on the daily chart because they could be range bound and not run too far.   
  
Both pairs (USD/CAD & AUD/JPY) may offer good pips but I am not convinced of the setups so I would prefer to stay out and look for something on the daily chart where the entry is in the same direction as an existing and strong trend. Far easier to make pips swimming in a big stream and going with the current than to swim against the flow or try and swim in a little stream that only comes up to your ankles.  
  
I discovered long ago (through lessons learnt the hard way) that trying to pick the start of a new trend and trading it is much like sliding down a wet rope with lots of razor blades sticking out of it. It hurts real bad and gets very messy!

The primary reason that I trade day charts is my availability to be in front of the screen, so for me, 4pm pst is the new day candle and I may set up trades at that time, however, I mainly trade in the 8pm to 10pm window. Dropping down to H4 is only something I do as part of MTFA to confirm PA on the Day.  
  
Certainly, as timeframes build, the moves start in the lower timeframes, but then there are more false signals. Also, if the pair is ranging, you can look to trade in the range and you can always do that on the lower timeframe. The original TMS and X-Man's thread is running on those scenarios - see post #1 for the links. Phx62 has some great posts on H1 trading techniques.  
  
Appreciate the question, but I am keeping this as a day chart thread - hope this clarifies the reasoning.

  * [![](https://assets.faireconomy.media/nfs/customavatars/thumbs/medium/avatar176273_2.gif) Britpip7](britpip7)

  * Joined Apr 2011 | Status: "Never Give Up - Never Surrender" | [1,608 Posts](/search?do=process&provider=Member&searchuser=176273)

Part of trading is keeping a journal of some description, and day charts allows you some time to devote to analyzing missed opportunities / losses and the wins.  
  
I always keep screen shots of all of my entries and final trade positions and then if I'm a really good boy I'll copy these into a powerpoint and add comments. This coupled with the account summaries / statements and I have a full story of my entry criteria / history of the trade and exit criteria.  
  
For the wins, it is just as important to review what went well, especially seeing as we all too often beat ourselves to a pulp on the losses!  
  
For my wins, I review the entry to see if I jumped the gun, was late or hit the goldilocks candle. Equally, did I get lucky off of a dodgy entry and it pulled back and now I look really cool sitting on a pot of lucky pips.  
  

  
Trading into conjestion / resistance / support  
  
False signal - trade reversed after valid entry criteria  
  
Entry signal was not optimal - reasons?  
  
Reversal didn't follow through - overall trend took prescedence  
  
Higher timeframes did not support the entry  
  
Aliens abducted the trade  
  
Shit happens  
  
What else?  
  
Happy journalling 

"To live with Passion, it takes Courage and Grace to survive"

That depends on what your trading business plan is.  
As for me, the risk per trade remains the same. My plan allows me to take trade multiple pairs, max up to 5 simultaneous ccy/pairs. thereby multiplying my risk 5xtimes on any trading day.  
Or I can divide my risk into 5 parts, each for one ccy/pair. This will change the position sizing per trade.  
At the end of the day, it is the reward to risk that matter.

I've just run through the charts for today and haven't seen any opportunities and it appears almost everything is consolidating and becoming range bound ... most pairs that yesterday had 2 candles up or down now have one going the other way so far today. Similar to Britpip, I end up checking the charts about 4 to 5 hours after the candle has closed - which isn't always a bad thing as it gives an idea of whether the trend is continuing or not on the day so far.  
  
When it gets like this, I always wonder what fundamentals may be causing it, and I believe it may be related to the following :  
  
\- German chancellor Angela Merkel said Greece would be the focus of talks at a meeting with International Monetary Fund director Christine Lagarde in Berlin today. Under a plan hammered out by euro zone leaders in October, investors in Greek bonds would have to accept a 50 per cent cut in the value of their holdings.  
\- Greece is nearer to a deal with bank creditors to wipe out 100 billion euros (NZ$161b) billion) from its huge debt, officials say ahead of talks with its European peers on a new bankruptcy-saving bailout.  
\- The European Central Bank will meet on Friday (GMT) to decide whether or not to cut interest rates. The meeting is heavily anticipated by investors who will be waiting to see the bank's view on Europe's current situation  
  
So it may be that things become range bound until one or both of these possible events force us out of the range. Of course, something else may force it ... you just never know!   
  
[Sources, not the greatest financial papers, but, if it's making our news here, you know it's big - [http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/n...ectid=10777987](http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10777987) ; [http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/n...ectid=10777974](http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10777974))

My trading plan is simple..I know it may sound strange to some people but thats what works for me  
  
I break even immediately i make 25pips then leave the trade running but close trade at the end of londons close of the 2nd day meaning i close the trade immediately when it approximately 41hours old  
  
I risk 10% of my account with 100pips stop loss..but it hardly hits this 100pips stop loss(1 out of 12trades)..i usually exit manually most time with around pips stop loss.  
  
i prefer trading one pair at a time. Noticed sometimes pairs may be correlating so i pick just one..i mean the one with the best setup.  
  
I took the USDCAD sell trade today and now in profit of about 20pips i decided to break even cos price is very close to support....now i have nothing else to loose in the trade..either i win or the trade ends up a break even trade**  
**Thats how i trade**

Hi guys,  
  
my first post here after reading a lot of threads (X-Man's, Trading Made Simple and this thread). Like many here I decided to get away from small timeframe charts and to trade h4 and daily charts.  
  
Therefore I have a question I asked before on other forums, but got different answers. It would be great to have a clear answer ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
Let's say I have a trade running and think it will continue next week. There is a SL in place.  
  
But what happens if the pair opens on Sunday evening (way) beyond the SL? In my opinion there are a few options:  
  
-The trade closes at the level it opens, because it's passed the SL. In this case the loss can be huge, even a margin call can happen.  
  
-The trade closes at the price level of your set SL. In this case the loss is your calculated loss.  
  
-The trade doesn't close because the SL actually never got hit. In this case the losses can be huge also if the pair drifts further away from your entry, but also can be good when it comes back.  
  
Anyone experienced something like this?  
  
Regards from the Netherlands!

Hi Britpip7  
  
The penny has finally dropped for me regarding the use of fractals for entry signals. Up till now I would typically wait for the close of the daily candle and then place an entry at market based on the confirmed TDI cross/bounce.   
  
This approach has been like taking one shot at a new signal setup and watching the long runs on pairs where I did not get in but not be able to do anything about it if I missed the TDI entry.  
  
Having done a lot of back testing and checking the role of fractals and the way you use them I can see their value in offering alternative new entry / add to existing trade options.   
  
It is amazing to see how often a fractal break correlates with a new TDI cross and there are plenty of opportunities to add extra lots to strong moves too.  
  
Thank you for sharing - this has added a new dimension to my daily chart trading and I will actively use fractals in combination with TDI now.

>

Fractals are a lagging indicator and will repaint until they are set per the rule set / definition.  
  
A fractal must have two preceding and two following bars with lower highs (higher lows, on a down move). Which means that a fractal will always be at least 3 candles old. I have been using it along with PA as an entry trigger point for some time and with the patterns that I show in the posts of trades and the training chart, they work very well.  
  
They indicate S/R points and this is the key issue and why they can be used for entry points. Check out the charts posted to date on this thread.

Hi everyone  
  
Just wanted to add my pennyworth. I noticed that some of you guys are entering trades at extreme levels of trend swings. What I'm getting at is that even in a down trend, of course, price action swings up (and vice versa). So it's really not a good idea to buy when price action is just about to swing down or sell when price action is just about to swing up. Your system doesn't seem to avoid this rather serious problem.   
There's a very easy way to avoid making this mistake and that's to only buy/sell around the swing axis. It's another system completely but my demo account's gone from $600 to $7000 in 6 weeks using it, so I kinda think this very simple system works. I'll elaborate if anyone's interested.  
  
Rgds

When there is nothing much happening, continue to back test and look for trade entry patterns.  
  
The more back testing you do, the better armed you are for picking up on the entry patterns.  
  
Here's another hindsight chart for training purposes - Trade 1 is a reversal trades - Trade 2 is more of a continuation trade.  
  
The two trade entries on the charts follow strong signal candles (Entries would have been on the 1st or 2nd candle following the signal / TDI cross), with a 5ema cross and higher highs. These are following the higher EMA lines and the PA is above all of the EMAs - on this chart, the strongest probability trades will be longs. This is re-enforced by the strong down candle in the ellipse which did not carry through with any great conviction. If this was taken, then the TDI hook would have been a good danger/exit signal (and may have cost you 100pips depending on how quickly you move your SL to BE) and coincided with Trade 2 entry.  
  
With Trade 1, the TP1 would have been achieved @ 2XATR(7) = 218pips. TP2 of 4XATR(7) would not have been met and would have depended upon your trade management skills - Max achievable was 400pips - a more likely result would be in the 200 to 300pips region.  
  
Trade 2 would have hit TP1 @ 2XATR(7) = 168pips as would TP2 @ 4XATR(7) = 336pips.  
  
Probable pip haul would have been in the region of 800 to 900pips. This was over a time period of 40 trading days, so a little under 7 weeks.

You mean in real words?   
  
OK - I'll give it a go.  
  
This was written for reversal trades. PA is for the Price Action move and is basically the signal candle (Change in colour / direction) - I will look to enter based on the next candle breaking the H/L of the signal candle.  
  
The ATR(7) provides you with the Average True (Trading) Range for the pair over the past 7 candles.  
  
Folks keep asking what size of candle should they use to enter a trade and I was basing my entries off of an individual candle - ATR(1), so I am looking for a strong signal candle to base my entry as many folks were just going after a colour change, so my entry rule was initially that I wanted the signal candle to be at least 50% the size of the ATR(7) value, but I prefer 75%.  
  
For example, if the current ATR(7) value is at 100pips, then I am looking for the signal candle to be at least 50pips and preferably 75pips or higher. This also means that I am looking for a larger body than wicks on the signal candle - no doji / pin bars, etc. - Refer to the latest training chart that I posted.  
  
Hope this helps

I don't know yet that is it going to be a trend reversal or pull back.  
  
Now the question is then why I took these trades when I knew nothing about it.   
  
I simply played support and resistance (you have already noticed that) - please see the horizontal lines on my charts defining the zones. Currently both these pairs are testing these lines on the reverse side.   
  
EURCAD - When the price reacted in the same fashion twice before when it reached around 1.2890 and also based on what had happened so far I knew that the chances are very high that this time price will go atleast another 100 pips before any further retracement. This expected 100 pip run will allow me to BE and once I am at BE I don't care what happend to the price. Normally I don't take trades just to make to BE but keeping in view the current status of EUR I thought it is worth testing the waters.   
  
CADCHF - The same story but on a flip side.  
  
Going against the major trend is like catching a falling knife unless one learns how to catch the knife and throw it back. If you look closely at any chart without any single indicator you will notice most of time trend changes when it reach either support or resistance. I am sure you have also noticed that TDI keep on dragging below 32 or above 50 till the price reach either support or resistance.  
  
In a nutshell a trader should keep an eye on support and resistance - the indicators due to its lagging nature simply gives a confirmation after the price moved atleast 100 pips depending on the pair and TF. Now, it boils down to the trader's style whether he wants to be 100 pips before the crowd or wait for the confirmation - it is a matter of choice.

You are bang on topic my friend.  
  
I have been referring to S/R levels especially relating to TDI crosses to make sure you are not trading into resistance or support levels.  
  
Currently, I am looking at entry points relating to strong S/R levels. The differing points of view relate to entering as the price pushes through or waiting for a candle to close above/below.  
  
As this week progressed - AUD/USD was in this situation as it approached the 1.0400 level and kept faltering / falling back and then finally has achieved a close nicely above 1.0400 at 1.0482.  
  
The challenge is as you pointed out - get in early ahead of the crowd or wait for confirmation of the break through?  
  
With the Day charts this involves patience and avoiding the need to enter a trade for a few pips. If you study some of the available material - either in FF on the threads, or in the numerous ebooks that circulate with the hope of hooking you for a subscription service, then you will see there is no real fixed rule for this type of entry - it all comes down to your trading style and your trading plans.  
  
My preference is to let the candle close and then follow the momentum of the PA. One very well written article that I have seen, talked to how momentum was perceived / interpreted. The focus was on the second half of the candle's life as this demonstrates the support and demand for the current PA. You can have a great bull push in the first half of the candle with new highs being set, only for the bears to take over which will leave you with a pull back candle with a large wick - this negates any momentum that was achieved earlier in the day. This often occurs around S/R levels and folks get faked out by the initial strength of the candle, only to watch it fall away at the end of the day.  
  
If, however, the bear push continues into the latter part of the day, then you have a strong momentum candle and if this succeeds in breaking the S/R, then look for continued momentum to drive the PA.  
  
This supports the Big E message that TDI crosses are not created equal and you still have to be on your game with the forex basics.

Just wanted to check in and give you my update.  
  
I continue to enjoy using the TMS method to trade and I have changed my approach a little since I started trading this method towards the end of December last year.  
  
For me the daily chart gives the best view of the 'big picture' per currency pair - on this time frame I find the TDI indicator and synergy bars to be very helpful in determining what the trend is doing etc.  
  
I do check the weekly chart from time to time to give me confidence when required before I enter a trade.  
  
My main chart for entries and exits however is the 4hr chart - I don't enjoy the discomfort of having to endure the possibility of relatively large moves against me that sometimes happens when taking trades off the daily chart. I still use TDI and synergy bars on the 4hr chart to pick solid entries with fairly tight stops (typically 30 - 60 pips) and then I use an 28ema as a trailing stop and this works very effectively to keep me in trades while the trend is strong, plus it allows the opportunity to move the stop to BE relatively quickly - which I like!  
  
I will continue to subscribe to this thread as I enjoy the contributions of Britpip7 and others but I will not post stuff that is off topic.  
  
Good trading everyone!

Thanks for the post - although the main goal is to stay true to the TMS approach, I am adding in my own approach as well as bringing in some of the older posts, as they are worth reading, so all posts relative to the approach are welcome.  
  
When it comes to managing the trades I often switch back and forth, although my usual approach is to moe my SL to the las L for longs, H fo shorts. I always find if I futz with the SL too much I get taken out and then whoosh - off it goes again.  
  
Here are some of Big E's posts ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f647-200d-2642-fe0f.png?v=15.1) from the time when he was really active and running the CH stochs thread. He had several approaches and this one uses the 21ema and 233ema. If this looks to be of interest, I suggest running some back tests on day charts and experimenting with the entries / add-ons. You may find that adding in the Fractals will also help. These are nice and clean charts - For the day charts I don't generally use the stochastics, but give it a try. It is always useful to have alternative approaches in the tool bag ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

Without the exact details of each setup, this cannot be answered, **HOWEVER ------**  
  
Money Management with Position Sizing is **EASY** , the only thing you have control of in **ANY** trade is the **RISK**.  
  
Basic procedure for every trade should be to know, ---  
  
**1\. Trigger** , why you are enter this trade? Do you have logical reason or are you just shooting like wild west?  
  
**2\. Stop Loss** , what will I accept as the point which invalidates #1?  
  
**3\. Entry point** , where to place a pending order that triggers when PRICE moves in the desired direction?  
  
The way to control **RISK** is to change the Position Size depending on the distance to the Stop Loss, use a calculator for this.  
  
Not the 2 examples, the stop distance has doubled, position size is approximately half but the **RISK** is always $200 or 2% of account size.  
  
This is **DAY** trading thread, so no reason why anyone can not plot these trades well in advance, price action ( just going up or down ) is the same for every time frame, this is 15 min but could be a daily chart.

Yes, a trade signal is a trade signal to my method; there are no degrees of probability, which I where I figure you are going with this line of questioning. See below ----  
  
**Trading in the Zone: The 5 Fundamental Truths**  
  
by Trader Rich   
  
I finished reading **"Trading in the Zone"** by Mark Douglas yesterday. For those of you who haven’t heard of it or read it, I would highly recommend it. Douglas doesn’t offer any specific strategies to becoming a successful trader but advises that the first step to becoming a successful trader is to accept the psychological realities of trading.   
  
A lot of what he advises, I have consciously accepted but the goal is for my subconscious to fully accept it so that it actually becomes part of who I am. Our beliefs are engrained in our minds and a lot of these beliefs don’t allow us to think like successful traders. The process by which we can start to think like successful traders involves "deactivating" these engrained beliefs and activate new beliefs. The new belief will take form and become part of our subconscious.  
  
**He mentions the importance of the 5 fundamental truths which we must train our minds to accept:  
**  
1\. Anything can happen  
  
2\. You don’t need to know what is going to happen next in order to make money  
  
3\. There is a random distribution between wins and losses for any given set of variables that define an edge  
  
4\. An edge is nothing more than an indication of a higher probability of one thing happening over another  
  
5\. Every moment in the market is unique   
  
**Here are his 7 principles of consistency:**  
  
1\. I objectively identify my edges  
  
2\. I predefine the risk of every trade  
  
3\. I completely accept the risk or I am willing to let go of the trade  
  
4\. I act on my edges without reservation or hesitation  
  
5\. I pay myself as the market makes money available to me  
  
6\. I continually monitor my susceptibility for making errors  
  
7\. I understand the absolute necessity of these principles. I never violate them. 

"Forex a Great Hobby, But Not a Great Job"

I have a similar view on this.  
  
If one demonstrates that a repeatable success rate is achieved over a pre-determined time, then you already have limited the risk associated with a trade entry.  
  
You must then understand what happens if within your probability of success, you experience a consecutive series of failures and the impact that would have on your account.  
  
I tend to scale up after a repeated series of successes, then if I have a failure I scale back until I have a succession of 3 successes and then it is back to the plan... Initiially I start out with 2% per entry and go from there.  
  
At the end of the day, it is all down to the trading plan and the money management / risk tolerance. You must accept that there will be losses and have an action plan to deal with the loss. That's why there is always cognac in the cupboard

This was posted as a possible set up for a trade once support had been broken - the Green/Red is setting up but you are correct in that it has not completed the cross - I was not planning an entry on this until a candle closed below the support anf then continued with PA.  
  
I posted a complete set of screenshots for my TMS Watchdog settings a while back as a pdf - it'll be in the attachments. This is just for the Inputs and not for the colour of the lines which I will add and update the pdf over the weekend. My RSI Green line is set to show the last candle move in Magenta - just my approach.  
  
The full TDI "guidelines" continually evolve, however, this is my approach:  
  
**Crossing UpZone and DnZone lines**  
When the Green (RSI Price Line - Line 4) crosses the UpZone (Green dotted - Line 1) going long - this can be seen as an add-on signal - when it crosses the UpZone going short, close positions.  
When the Green crosses the DnZone (Green dotted - line 3) going short- this can be seen as an add-on signal - when it crosses the UpZone going long, close positions.  
  
**Role of the Mid Zone**  
If the Green is crossing the Red (line 5 - Trade Signal Line) going long and they are doing so above the Mid Zone (Blue line), then this is often seen as a higher probability long entry position.   
If the Green is crossing the Red going short and they are doing so belowthe Mid Zone, then this is often seen as a higher probability short entry position.   
  
**TDI Crosses**  
Not all Green/Red crosses are entries but they are certainly a heads up to go look at the Price Action and verify the move. If there is a valid set-up candle, then look to enter on the next candle as the PA/momentum continues - this will also reinforce the TDI cross.  
Green/Red Crosses from above the 68, often indicate a reverse - be aware of the possibility of a fakeout if this is near S/R levels.  
Green/Red Crosses from below the 32 often indicate a reverse - be aware of the possibility of a fakeout if this is near S/R levels.  
Once a candle closes, the TDI positions are locked and they are only in motion during the current candle's life time.

From the Set Up Candle I look for the entry based on the SUC H/L. Ususally there will be a wick to the SUC so the entry point is taken when the H/L of the wick is broken.  
  
If the H/L of the SUC is not broken, then I do not have an entry. I can then do the following:  
  
a) leave the pending trade in place until the entry point is achieved - this can take several candles so extreme patience is required.  
  
b) cancel the pending trade and wait for another SUC.  
  
If the TDI flattens out then PA is stalling.  
  
The momentum of a day candle is dictated by what it does in the final 6 hours of it's life. If it pulls back, then wait for PA to resume.  
  
I MUST have PA to confirm the TDI cross / bounce.  
  
There are a number of training charts that show Set Ups and Entries - Keep watching for new charts / examples.

Limited options on this as it does happen.  
  
1\. let it run for at least one full candleand then make the call - usually I will let it run for 3 candles before making a decision or until the SL is triggered.  
  
2, Close and look for another option - depends how close this is to S/R (Check out the gbp/aud - good example of nothing really setting up) - I have modified my entry rule for trading S/R breaks, but if it the PA does stall then I am looking to exit and re-enter following a close below/above the S/R

This is a chart set up that I am testing for the Day Chart (the Big E set up was actually 21/233 and I have adjusted the template accordingly) - I do still use the TDI and as part of my back testing processes I will try out other methods to see if the results differ with different approaches.  
  
The 21/233 EMA approach was a technique that Big E was using on the lower timeframes before the TMS Thread was started. Basically when 21 crosses 233 go long and add on - opposite for going short.  
  
I am adapting this to my Day Chart trading approach.  
  
Essentially my methodology stays true to Post #1 - the indicators may vary, but the approach is pure Price Action.  
  
If all of the entry criteria line up, the resulting trade has a high probability of succeeding.

Ja - I am still really focused on the PA - I did start using Heikin Ashi and then switched to ATD but now mostly use traditional candles. Regardless of the indicators, there are always opportunities for false signals but the day charts do minimize the risk.  
  
What I do like about the ATD is the colour change and in particular the configuration of a good set-up candle. So the real answer is that I'll often look for the set up with both charts running - sometimes overlaying the price bars onto ATD to verify PA/momentum.  
  
Big E had always pointed out, once the colour change occurs you will on average get 3 to 8 additional candles of the new colour. However, you still must pay attention to your entry candles, especially where the PA is stalling or does not follow through, which is when you do need to watch the actual candles/price bars and/or drop down to get a better view of PA.  
  
Attached is a great example of APB not following expectations and stalling out even though the set up candle low did run 40pips lower than the colour change candle low. Price stalled and now you are stuck with a stalled trade going into a weekend - unfortunate, but it can happen. By the way, this trade entry broke my entry criteria, so another great example of following your trading plan to keep you out of less than AAA entries!

As the trading range narrows over a longer period of time, the EMAs flatten out as does the TDI which will drift back to 50 as will the RSI, so no momentum.  
  
Quite a few examples of this - E/U, NZ/U, GB/NZ, EU/NZ, EJ  
  
Now watch for breakouts on your favourite pairs - candles to close above/below the range with TDI cross and PA momentum

Congratulations on exiting from a low probability set up - that is excellent.  
  
Upon discovering that you are in a trade that on reflection reveals that you should not be - close it! Do not sit in the trade and turn it into a "Hope Trade".  
  
What I have seen more often is that when I have a trade that triggers or that I enter and then the PA stalls, often the pair will move into consolidation mode. Once you lose the momentum, the pair can do anything - the set-up / entry signal was therefore not valid.  
  
Better to exit and look for new opportunities than sit in a trade and watch it drift away and eventually hil the SL.
