TDI thoughts and observations.  
  
Generally, the TDI Mid Zone / Trade base line (blue) likes to be around the 50 level. If it strays to the 32 / 68 zones, or even breaks through these zones, then PA will very likely reverse.  
  
Any time the TDI Trade Signal Line and the RSI Price Line break the 32 . 68 levels, watch for reversals.  
  
The Trade Signal line also gives some clues on where PA is heading. the attached chart shows horizontal sky blue lines to highlight the Trade Signal Line reversing.  
  
It is not normal to have a strong TDI entry signal if the cross goes against the direction of the Trade Signal Line. What this means is that when the Trade Signal Line is heading down and the RSI Price Line crosses and heads up, this is probably not going to be supported by PA,  
  
Notice how the Trade Signal Line flattens out after a trend run and once there is an APB colour change, the PA will confirm the TDI Cross. Wait for the second candle to confirm the PA and wait for the Trade Signal Line to confirm the direction and you will have stronger entries. Just for fun, I expanded the Indicator Window 2 to really show how this looks.  
  
We are always looking for the silver bullet to get in earlier, however, if you can increase the probability of a successful trade entry but you have to give up 10 or 20 pips to do so, would you?  
  
Anyway, here's another brilliant hindsight training chart that may show you how it should look - now ll you have to do is make it work on a live chart!  
  
For back testing, use the 1 X ATR7 value for your TP1 and see how many times it is hit for your favourite pair. Then see what happens if you use 2XATR7 for TP2. Play with the values and keep lots of notes / spreadsheets. Build you stats and figure out your probability of success for the settings.  
  
Happy pip hunting

Following on from posts regarding the TDI Trade Signal Line and allowing it to flatten or reverse so that when the TDI cross occurs the Trade Signal Line is heading in the same direction as PA, here's an H4 chart for review.  
  
Because the TDI cross occurs before the APB Colour change, the entry point could be taken early, or wait until PA confirms. As this is H4, there are multiple Add-On opportunities.  
  
With H4 trades, I will often use the ATR 7 setting from the Day chart for TP1, so this would yield 60 pips for TP1 and TP2 plus add-ons would give you over 400pips to date.  
  
A good example of an H4 entry followed by add-ons for pip farming

AG,  
  
Waiting for the A+ set-ups is what makes the difference, so, essentially not placing trades and hoping they work out. Wait for PA to really confirm the move and if you are using indicators or patterns including supply and demand zones, wait for the previous candle (set up candle) to close and then either at the end of the candle or at the beginning of the new candle make your decisions.  
  
I am placing less trades with waiting for the move to confirm, but see better results.  
  
I would avoid the approach that increases risk - I want to see safe and boring trades. The GU training chart that I posted was a high probability low risk trade - this is what I look for to increase my pip yields. Managing your trades once they are in profit and giving your trades space to breathe will help as will cutting the losing trades after it is clear that the PA is not following your rules.  
  
The two biggest reasons for traders not making profits are:  
  
1\. Cutting a profitable trade too early  
2\. Keeping a losing trade running for too long and hoping it will turn around (this is probably the hardest skill to perfect because nobody likes losing!!!).

Greetings All,  
  
Been playing around with TDI and seeing what would be possible with a single screen MA approach and de-cluttering the screen. Always looking at options for simplifying the data and the entry criteria.  
  
This closely replicates what the TDI does with the benefit of keeping everything on the main chart - I do have RSI as a second window open for posting the RSI value in my Data screen, so displaying it as a chart is optional, but sort of defeats the objective of the single screen approach -you can always compress it - may work better as a displayed chart on the lower timeframes.  
  
If you backtest, always disable the fractals and be aware that the overall trend of the MAs once set are influenced by where the next candle went, so an F12 test gives you a good idea, but live testing will give different results - personally I prefer looking at the screen to see how to differentiate between good entry signals and ones that stalled out / failed.  
  
The MA crosses are very close to the TDI - usually same candle and does on occasion filter out false TDI crosses, so worth a live experiment for forward testing - you can always add in the TDI to compare as you test.  
  
Looking to continue with the adapted TDI rule where the slower MA has to flatten out and adopt the same direction as the PA - slightly slower entry criteria, but has more probability of success. Looks good on Day and H4, but that would be as low as I would go on timeframes.  
  
The usual rules on the 100/200EMAs apply - see Post #1 - also on candle patterns - engulfing / inside bar / pull back / pin bar / shooting star / hammer, all help support the entry criteria  
  
the arrows are taken from an indicator that I think came from Lawgirl's threads and has been modified for this approach - these are more of a head's up indicator and to verify the pattern / slope of the slow MA and PA. When you see multiple arrows of the same colour, this usually results in a move in the direction indicated. Everything else is from my original charts.  
  
for RSI 10, I am using <49 for shorts and >51 for longs, unless the Day entry is really strong - RSI will lag especially on the Day.  
  
The attached chart is H1 which shows RSI 10 as a valid signal to confirm entries - so with the example on H1, each valid entry and 2 entry positions, would have yielded a total of over 200 pips over a 10 period when PA was pretty much range trading, so trading H1 and M15 is always an option in these conditions

Interpreting the APB colour changes on Day can be challenging.  
  
On the current GU, we have had several single day colour changes - here's how I am looking at them.  
  
First of all, when monitoring the day charts, I will see the colour change at the end of the day, so this means that PA changed during the previous day and changed the colour, so dropping down to H4 and in some cases H1 and looking for confirmation helps me to verify what PA is doing for the next couple of candles. This will be the start of the Asian session, so can be pretty quiet, but is worth doing.  
  
PA breaks of the Asian channel can be very productive, but follow the major trend unless you are scalping the pause / pull back  
  
The H4 chart also gives you Add-On options when you see a new MA cross

For those of us eagerly awaiting the reversals of the AUD based currencies, bear in mind the link to gold. AUD is a commodity based currency and closely follows gold. CAD does a similar thing with oil.  
  
Gold has had a long run up and was fueled in part by world economies faltering. As these economies recovered, gold lost its appeal. So, for AUD to reverse, gold needs to have some strength. Maybe G8 and FOMC may shed some light on the directions, but PA is still key.  
  
AUD could just as easily continue recent trend runs. Wait for clear breaks of current ranges and keep your money management tight.

Hi David,  
  
Reminds me of years ago when the McClellans talked about waiting for a buy spike on their oscillator when trading equities. Takes lots of patience for the longer trends. Even a solid TDI cross on the Weekly usually needs to prove itself with continuing strong separation as RSI and the Signal cross through 50. Frequently I see that to be the best entry configuration with the highest likelihood for multiple add-ons. Even more so if this is preceeded by a period of low volatility in proximity to the 200 MA. I know, lots of requirements, but the payoff can be huge even if only a few times a year.  
  
Best, AG

I now focus on 12 pairs and have these on 12 up charts for PA and TDI - I have these set up in Profles and have them set for Day / H4 and H1.  
  
It's easy to set up - go to profiles and click on Default.  
  
Create a chart and save it as a template - right click and go to Template and Save Template.  
  
Open 12 new charts for the pairs you trade - doesn't have to be 12 - your choice - and set them up from your template folder to the chart set up that you use and then go to Window and click Tile Vertically. then save the profile.  
  
You can scan the day and h4 profiles for TDI activity / crosses, then go to the PA profile and then click on the pair that has crossed and trade away.

Hi David,  
  
I am a big fan of this approach but because I am looking for the longer term Trends, I add the Weekly TF for a bigger picture view. I also smooth the HA candles, n=2, for starker contrasts. The best Trends will then be a bit easier to spot with persistent color change, growing candles and the absence of near side wicks. The reappearance of near side wicks can be a clue that time may be growing short for the Trend long before a color change. I hope that you do not mind, but I have enclosed an example.

From onlinetradingconcepts.com  
  
The Hanging Man candlestick formation, as one could predict from the name, is a bearish sign. This pattern occurs mainly at the top of uptrends and is a warning of a potential reversal downward. It is important to emphasize that the Hanging Man pattern is a warning of potential price change, not a signal, in and of itself, to go short.  
[http://www.onlinetradingconcepts.com...gingManPic.gif](http://www.onlinetradingconcepts.com/images/candlesticks/HangingManPic.gif)  
The Hanging Man formation, just like the[Hammer](http://www.onlinetradingconcepts.com/TechnicalAnalysis/Candlesticks/Hammer.html), is created when the open, high, and close are roughly the same price. Also, there is a long lower shadow, which should be at least twice the length of the [real body](http://www.onlinetradingconcepts.com/TechnicalAnalysis/Candlesticks/CandlestickBasics.html).  
When the high and the open are the same, a bearish Hanging Man candlestick is formed and it is considered a stronger bearish sign than when the high and close are the same, forming a bullish Hanging Man (the bullish Hanging Man is still bearish, just less so because the day closed with gains).  
After a long uptrend, the formation of a Hanging Man is bearish because prices hesitated by dropping significantly during the day. Granted, buyers came back into the stock, future, or currency and pushed price back near the open, but the fact that prices were able to fall significantly shows that bears are testing the resolve of the bulls. What happens on the next day after the Hanging Man pattern is what gives traders an idea as to whether or not prices will go higher or lower.

After testing a variety of formats, I am keeping the TDI on the chart because it does give some good confirmations which you may otherwise miss.  
  
TDI is an overlay onto a MACD which is there as a general momentum indicator - The OSMA Oscillator is very similar, and the Awesome Oscillator is also good - but pick one and go with it.  
  
The RSI may be too much on top of all of this, but knowing the value is a good thing.  
  
All the rules are intact, so no changes there. The colours work for me with my colour vision issues, so feel free to make it work for you.  
  
The main chart has lost the Supply and Demand Zones because mostly they were sitting on the primary Weekly S/R price lines, so once you zoom out and fix them, they will not repaint as the zones do when PA hits them.  
  
The White arrows are the 2/7 EMA confirmation and I am currently testing with the Black arrows which are 5/10 EMA confirmations - they may not add anything, so could well get nuked in the next version.  
  
So no need to add any wierd indicators - Big E would be non too impressed by the additions, but they seem to help - it's all a personal choice at the end of the day.  
  
Happy pip hunting

I'm a beginner with this method and I must say I really like it. Going to demo trade until I get the hang of things. Here's the first trade I've been in using this method  
  
[http://i1303.photobucket.com/albums/...psd48319e2.png](http://i1303.photobucket.com/albums/ag157/ForexScreenshots/2013-08-02_1837_zpsd48319e2.png)  
  
I made the mistake first of going in too early and setting my stop loss too tight. I set it at the recent low which was only ~30 pips and price just barely hit the stop loss before going back up. Also the red signal line hadn't started going in the upwards direction, so I jumped in too early.  
  
When the red signal line did start going up I went long on the high of the candle (swear I wasn't revenge trading, I thought it out for quite some time). Overall I think it was a decent trade, and so far it looks like momentum is picking up. Couple things I liked about this trade  
  
Pros  
\- APB color change, doji candle right before it, also if you look at the candles preceding, it looks like the bearish candles were losing steam.  
\- Overall long term trend is up (weekly, 100 + 200 EMA)  
\- TDI cross under the 50 level  
\- RSI(10) just crossed the 50 mark when trade was taken  
\- ATR(1) was > 75% of ATR(7) and the set up bar had a substantial body, with some upper + lower wick  
\- Price touched the 100 EMA which acted as support and started going up from there  
  
Cons  
\- Resistance level overhead, although I think price will break through it.

Here is a great example for what NFP can do to what would appear to be a great set up.  
  
Trading before NFP is like rolling the dice - you have no idea what will happen, so if you like your odds at 50/50 then go place all your money on black and go to Vegas.  
  
This example, depending on how you placed your trade - pending as a sell stop or a by market sell, would either have not triggered if you set your Entry Point below the Thursday Low, or you would be sitting 190pips if placed as a sell by market.  
  
As Nancy Reagan would say - Just say No to placing trades before NFP - same advice applies to FOMC news events!  
  
Happy pip hunting

Here is the current template and screenshots of the indicators plus weekly / daily / H4 and H1 charts  
  
This is from an earlier post  
After testing a variety of formats, I am keeping the TDI on the chart because it does give some good confirmations which you may otherwise miss.  
  
TDI is an overlay onto a MACD which is there as a general momentum indicator - The OSMA Oscillator is very similar, and the Awesome Oscillator is also good - but pick one and go with it.  
  
The RSI may be too much on top of all of this, but knowing the value is a good thing.  
  
All the rules are intact, so no changes there. The colours work for me with my colour vision issues, so feel free to make it work for you.  
  
The main chart has lost the Supply and Demand Zones because mostly they were sitting on the primary Weekly S/R price lines, so once you zoom out and add the S/R lines as Horizontal Lines, they will not repaint as the zones do when PA hits them.  
  
The White arrows are the 2/7 EMA confirmation and I am currently testing with the Black arrows which are 5/10 EMA confirmations - they may not add anything, so could well get nuked in the next version.

Expanding a bit on the Weekly Reversals observation.  
  
When the Weekly candles show an engulfing pattern, this is a heads up that the trend has a high probability of reversing.  
  
The stronger the initial engulfing candle, the higher the probability of success, so if the engulfing candle pattern is achieved with one candle, this is stronger than a reversal patterns that takes two candles to achieve the full cover of the previous candle.  
  
These weekly / engulfing reversal patterns look to precede any TDI Cross confirmation and as for the 2/7EMA, this may also come too late on the live charts - looks encouraging on this chart, but not sure how far into the week it triggers - just there as an information point at this time and one to watch for live / forward testing.  
  
As usual, this is work in progress going forward - may be useful to back test this as it is just candle patterns and no indicators involved (remove the fractals and the 2/7 arrows for back testing), but definitely worth bearing in mind that the Weekly chart always drives the momentum and probability of the day chart move.

Time to analyze a trade that is actually in process as opposed to completed trades or hindsight training charts.  
  
EA Weekly Chart was on a very strong up trend, however, MACD is showing a strong bearish divergence and TDI has flattened, so technically a Bearish signal. especially being heavily oversold,  
  
EA Day Chart was showing the initial PA running out of steam with MACD, RSI 10 and TDI RSI Price Line all rolling over on the last 2 white APB candles. TDI Trade Signal Line has nicely rolled over, making a TDI cross very strong for the reversal. TDI is then supporting the PA move.  
Once the APB colour change candle closes, you have a potential Entry Point - this would have caught the Entry Point #2 on the H4 Chart. This Entry Point would have triggered on the 3rd black APB candle.  
  
The 2/7EMA confirmation arrow appears after the close of the 3rd black APB candle, so this provides another entry signal.  
  
EA H4 chart shows how to look at PA when the Day Chart is giving an indication of a move and then starts to roll over.  
  
The H4 chart was showing TDI Bearish Divergence against the PA, so the set up is there several candles before the first TDI cross and well in advance of the signals on the Day chart. Entry Point #1 as it turned out was not a strong running one as it initially went for 110pips and then suffered a 55pip drawdown before Entry Point 2 was confirmed with the TDI Cross and a Fractal Low break. This time the PA move is stronger until it takes a four candle rest (go to YouTube and watch "four candles" by the two Ronnies - hilarious) and then resumes the trend for Entry Position 3, which is the one that I am riding.  
  
For additional Add-Ons, watch this on H4 or H1, but for my trade, it will depend on how much gap we see on Sunday, especially as I only have 20 pips left from my trailing stop of 65pips - maybe I should have closed the trade before Friday close, but with 100pips locked in, I'm prepare to risk 65 for a longer trade run and Add-Ons.  
  
Happy pip hunting

Trade Summary for the week.  
  
13 trades set up for pending trades (buy stops / sell stop) which is a really high number of trades in a week for me.  
  
10 trades triggered (including one oops with a sell by market instead of a pending sell stop - don't ask - which was immediately closed so that I stick to the trading plan!)  
  
9 profits and 1 loss (including a couple of BE stop outs after the trades were in profit), this includes the current trade with 100pips locked in.  
  
Pips won 32/99/4(BE)/68/29/2(BE)/18/18/100 = 370  
  
Pips lost 3(oops trade - sell by market) = 3  
  
Win to Loss Ratio 370/3 which is not bad  
  
This is my best ever win/loss ratio since going live (and I would have to say is an exceptional result - certainly not typical), so we shall see how this pans out over the next few weeks. I spend about 2 hours per day analyzing and placing the set ups and closing the trades. These were all pending trades that triggered while I was sleeping and then the closure is one of 4 scenarios:  
  
a) hit TP target  
b) closed when I woke up  
c) closed after setting to run with TS  
d) closed later in the day on a pull back / PA stall  
  
Just to confirm, this is a live account and the current lot size is 0.02, so $20 per trade. Risk per trade is below 5% and they key is to watch your total exposure when trading multiple pairs. Same rules apply when you start adding on to winning positions - understand how many trades you are opening and what your total risk is.  
  
It may look really impressive in a demo account having 20+ trades open, but if you get a bad news result / central bank announcement / natural disaster - earthquake, then all those pending pips will reverse on you. No harm in the demo, but do this with real money and there will be tears - ask me how I know this ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f910.png?v=15.1)  
  
If JPY is on a trend run, then pick 2 of the strongest pairs - same with any of the currencies, otherwise you will risk over trading and blow your account.   
  
Happy pip hunting - looking forward to next week ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)

USD CHF looks to be hitting a very strong weekly support line, so this sets up a Demand Zone - watching for a bounce higher - opposite of EU and GU of course.  
  
EJ The gap between RSI Price Line and Trade Signal Line on TDI is closing on the day chart (Weekly shows TDI Bearish Divergence for quite a while), so currently no new entries on the day unless PA breaks below 128.00 - next major weekly support is 250 pips away - H4 gives a better entry view for the next few candles.  
  
EUR NZD following the 125pip gap last week which was closed and then some, looks to be stuck in a 700pip range, so with the current move at 500pips, then this one is watch and see. Looks like PA is respecting the 89EMA line, so no surprise if this pattern repeats.  
  
AUD CAD weekly is still down and using the 7EMA as dynamic resistance, so probability for the current PA to respect the trend line is high, however RSI is now >51 and TDI is still moving higher. The gap between RSI Price Line and TDI Trade Signal Line concerns me, so this would be another danger signal for going long before the trend line is broken.  
  
Eur CAD and GBP CAD both show the same. EUR CAD Weekly is pulling back from recent highs and the Day chart pull back, APB colour change and TDI cross all look good. A break of the current Day trend lows would be more evidence of the reversal.

Quieter week this week on the trading front due to a heavier work schedule, so little time to focus - ended up 60 pips down for the week due to closing two trades too early - each would have gone on to hit their respective TPs.  
  
A comment from another thread by claudia1 would be worth understanding.  
  
She wrote in response to the question - What's the win rate thus far?  
  
"Win rate is irrelevant its how you manage the trades is what its all about. Can lose 70% of trades and still be in profit. to answer your question i do win 70% of trades manually at around one to to one risk reward."  
  
This is a typical FF question from folks trawling through threads looking for the silver bullet / holy grail.  
  
To expand a tad more on this. If you trade for an institution, no one cares about your win rate. If your win rate is 70% but you end up with some real stinkers that kill your account, what good was the win rate? Claudia1's point is well made and you should concentrate on minimizing your risk in order to maximize your profits. Understand what your A+ entry conditions are and follow your plan.   
  
A better measurement is $ won versus $ lost, or % gain in the account, etc.  
  
Phx62 has made similar comments when asked these types of questions and points out that no two individuals trade the same, so knowing one person's results, although gratifying, is actually of little use. All it will tell you is whether a trader is consistent in their approach and disciplined in their following their trading plans and money management plans.

As I had mentioned earlier on this thread that I was developing an H4 strategy based on the Day PA & TDI, I thought I would see how accurate it will be going forward, so I will be posting trade forecasts next week based on the following news alerts on selective currencies, so fingers crossed file:///C:UsersDavidAppDataLocalTempmsohtmlclip11clip_image001.gif Sometimes the news events from one currency coincide with others - especially CAD and USD.  

I am using GBP as my baseline currency for all trades.  

The order instructions will be one of the following - sell by market (SBM), buy by market (BBM), pending sell stop (PSS), pending buy stop (PBS).  

I will post these between 9pm and 9:30pm Pacific / California time which is the time I normally set my trades up on the daily charts.  

I will also give updates each day at the same time as to whether or not to close the trade or add-on. also if I see something during the day, I will also post an update - this is usually to close a trade. Some of these news events will be a one day trade but in cases where the news event is significant, it will start/continue a trend run for a few days, so good opportunities for some pip farming (this will also be the case where news events feed into one another such as CAD Employment and Ivey PMI).  

Not sure how the timing will work on the AUD news – this is all part of the live test.  

At the end of the week I will post the results - nothing like live testing in one of the major news weeks on a forum to test the approach ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f630.png?v=15.1)

Well my friend, in part, this is a development resulting from your consistency in trading the H1 charts with TMS. I started mapping your trades as well as trades on the Third Screen Strategy and was seeing consistent patterns. The challenge was to replicate your success but with the Day TMS and H4 PA charts.  
  
The theory holds water and with all of the backtesting completed which has taken over 2,000 data points per pair, across multiple time frames (think I may have worn out the F12 key ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)). The yields look encouraging, but then they always do when there is nothing at stake. So now it is time to prove the theory with live / forward testing. September should be a fun month, as I plan to run this for the next 4 weeks, so long as the day job does not interfere!

1- Which trend do you follow: Daily, weekly, or monthly? or what combination of trends that must line up to trade? [e.g. daily and weekly!] I use the weekly for S/R levels as well as overall trend - sometimes you will have pullbacks on the day chart that are tradeable, but all my entry signals are form the day charts.  
  
2- What should I do when price for no reason stalls? once you lose your initial trade entry signals, all bets are off and it is a 50/50 call - best bet, cancel and start again - look for new entry positions  
  
3- Is there any way to know whether the price is going to breach the supp and demand zones or not! not really - PA is king and it will tell you where it wants to go - no predictive indicators I'm afraid.  
  
4- Do you keep the trade going when it reaches these zones? If you have two trades running you can close one and manage the second - I am inclined to close and wait for the next signal.

For noobs like myself:  
1- Trust the system if it makes sense and try to follow it. Don't break your own rules!  
2- Give the price room to breathe. All the trades I lost wasn't because of the system, but because I closed it immediately when the price started ranging away from it's predicted direction.. But the next day I found it booming in my favor after I closed the trade. Or because I put a small SL range!  
3- If you're using TMS hist indicator, I found that when Daily trend is up and gave you a signal, but W & MN are down, it might be a lazy or short movement like what is happening now in EUR/USD [The only exception is when the PA is bouncing off of a supply and demand zones or S/R levels [including 200ema].  
.....  
  
I took this trade 2 days ago and it wasn't moving, but now I'm in profit +56 pips. my tp target is just beneath the coming supply zone. Moved my SL to BE.

This is where opening two trades per entry will help.  
  
TP1 = 1 X ATR 7  
  
TP2 - leave to run - move to BE after TP1 is hit and then manage / add-on as appropriate.  
  
Currently EUR/CAD day PA is approaching a Supply Zone, so may not be a great example, however, following the two trades theory, with my current trades - TP1 would have closed out for 130pips, leaving TP2 to run which is currently at 200pips with an add-on.  
  
For SL settings once a trend run has been established and the Day candles have stayed above the EMA7 for a few days, I will often use the H4 Fractals (Fractal Lows for the up trend), or previous Day Low to track the trend.  
  
Once the H4 moves above the 68 level, I will normally wait for a pause / mini retrace before a new add-on, of for PA to break a Fractal high.  
  
If the H4 PA starts to close below the H4 EMA 7, this is a heads up that consolidation / pull back is coming, so manage accordingly.

Mr Brit, allow me to address noobs like my self again:  
  
After massive backtesting, I can tell you hints:  
If you're lost and can't keep up analyzing charts like Mr Brit, and you can't even achieve profits like his, you can stick to some basic rules:  
1- Show the market base line [the yellow line] in your TDI and add level [50]. Buy when ever both green and red line are above yellow line and level 50 and the opposite for short positions. [this will protect you from trading against the overall trend, because the yellow line represents the trend]  
2- Pay good attention to divergence [regular and hidden] if an uptrend is making higher highs and TDI is making lower highs, you don't need to wait TDI to cross level 50 and market base line, enter the trade as soon as TDI crossover occurs.  
3- Money management is the most important thing. If you chose to apply these conservative conditions for trading, you can divide your trades by Targeting more than 2 or 3 TP starting by [0.5XATR] then [1XATR}...etc  
4- I don't stick to 2% trades, I always use mini lots in my 1K account.  
5- You'll get 2 or 3 conservative trades for each pair / month. If you're trading mini lots.. do the math.  
6- Stick to daily charts and avoid keeping open trades during the weekend [because of the gaps].  
8- Don't trade any pair on demo or live before doing manual backtesting for it [usually I do the backtesting using LHF simulator for a whole year]  
  
These rules are very conservative with moderate but guaranteed profits till you gain confidence in this trading style, then you can improvise like Mr. Brit.  
  
Mourad  
Egypt

It is worth noting here that the M15 can be traded within the overall trends / retraces, so this means trading counter to the Day / week, so if we are running with a long on the day, US brokers will not allow a short - no hedging.  
  
For those of us that can trade the M15 and the day, you will need two accounts in the USA so that you can run with the longer term trades and then pick up the pauses / pull backs.  
  
For those of us that do not have that luxury, then it is much simpler - trade the Day / H4 and sleep well ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f911.png?v=15.1) ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

Following on from the current PA on GU and touching on some comments on the TMS thread, the GU has a large Master Candle at the moment of 270 pips.  
  
Additionally PA is sitting underneath a Day Supply Zone and a Weekly S/R level.  
  
These candles can be traded in a couple of ways - first with regards to the day charts, treat them as an Inside Candle set up and wait for the breakout, second, drop down to the lower timeframes. Once the second day candle does not break the H/L, then it is a reasonable move to drop down and trade the range, and in many cases this will result in hitting the breakout move when it finally appears.  
  
Here's the Day Master Candle and the resulting H1 chart

Target wise you could be right, we may find support around 96.6 where a reversal happens, if i get a long signal to enter I will be targetting historic swing levels e.g. 98.950 / 99.690 / 100.585 and so on. just my take on things ....

I generally will not take trades against the MACD direction.  
  
Once MACD flattens or starts to pull back, that is usually a sign of consolidation - typically it will coincide with Day PA reaching a weekly S/R region of a Supply / Demand Zone.  
  
If the MACD resumes, then the trend is continuing and look for new entries.

For the CCI 14, I am testing it with the MACD.   
Currently the initial results seem to support the theory that when MACD is stalling on a long position and then starts to decrease, CCI will reduce and cross the +100. This is an early warning of price reversal and time to either close the long positions or at least bring the SL up to most recent H4 Fractal Low. There are occasions where this will only result in a price stall and then consolidation. EU is looking promising - hence the pending short sell.  
Opposite for Short positions  
  
Blue line on H4 is EMA7 - Simple - typical - shift 0  
  
Same for the Day except shift of 1

All open trades have been closed as everything has slowed down significantly which means any signals that were in play are now waiting for the next push, so I will sit to the side and see where they go.  
  
While everything has slowed down it gives us a chance to relax and have some screen time without distractions of trading. When I set my charts up I always add on the Weekly S/R levels from the historical levels.  
  
To do this I start off with just the main chart window, so all other indicator windows have been switched off by using the indicator properties window and by deselecting the weekly timeframe to leave yourself with candles. From that point add horizontal lines at the significant reversal levels - I use the Weekly Close. I will often add text to each level so that I can refer to it later. One thing that will often happen is that a Weekly S/R level will occur at a Big Round Number, which is often cited as a "psychological level" for traders (possibly self fulfilling prophesies!). Sometimes instead of a definitive price point, there will be a zone which can be up to 100 pips.  
  

  
I find that this helps with a certain level of prediction for PA losing momentum as it reaches these levels, so either exiting trades as PA closes in on an S/R level or managing with tighter stop losses are options.  
  
Common moves at these levels are consolidation / bounces and reversals.

Measures for success on your trading plans  
  
Do Not worry too much about your overall Profit Trades as a % of total - you may have lots of B/E or small profit trades which will skew the stats.  
  
Do worry about the following:  
  
Gross Profit = total $ won  
  
Gross Loss = total $ lost  
  
Total Net Profit = Gross Profit minus Gross Loss  
  
Profit Factor = Gross Profit divided by Gross Loss - this is the number to focus on. To get this number higher, set yourself goals on each trade and rules as to how many pips you are prepared to give up on a winning trade (trailing stops, cave manager, etc?), as well as SL settings and how you manage losing trades (once a trade goes against you, how many pips are you willing to lose?).  
  
Here's my final numbers for December - very pleased with the month as I often have other commitments in my schedule which conflict with trading every day. Only 17 trades and only trading with 0.02 lots = $20 per trade. Depending on your account size and risk management, this level of trading can be a good supplement to your income, so if you trade with 0.1 lots, your income multiplies by 5, and so on!  
Maybe that's the New Year resolution - trade on a more consistent basis with larger volumes - we shall see ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
Happy pip hunting on 2014 - may all your pips be green

I still check in with the TMS thread to see who is posting and pick up any nuggets.  
  
Emmanuel is posting again and pulling up some of BigE's posts - here is a good one for TDI and entries:  
  
[http://www.forexfactory.com/showthre...16#post4575616](http://www.forexfactory.com/showthread.php?p=4575616#post4575616)  
  
The reference to HA candles should be read as the APB candles  
  
  
  
  
The TDI is the heart of our method. It tells you when to enter and where to exit any trades... so review previous posts and learn it good.  
  
HA / APB Candles are important because it makes your trading way less stressful... use them.  
  
Stoch's is nothing but confirmation. If Stoch's & the TDI give different signals... lights flash off and on warning me to take a closer look before entering.. and usually I look for another trade.  
  
... only wanting to enter on candle 1 or two (after TDI cross / APB clor change - my edit!) . If there is a reversal do I have a TDI signal to enter... if not and all looks strong then enter on candle 2... use some discretion... practice on Demo... take some chances and see if yor head computer was right... it's free.  
  
HA - APB Candles... What are their size? If they are small I will usually go find another set up... Look for consolidation... look for how close PA is to supp/res levels... use your brain !  
  
Believe it or not you have to participate and think... until it's so second nature... there is nothing to it... it's so simple... don't complicate it or you will lose...

Oldie,  
  
A good entry on the Day Chart with a new colour APB, new colour MACD and TDI cross. PA looks to have run into an old Weekly S/R level from 2009 on the Day chart and is also running into EMA89 and EMA200 levels on H4, so unlucky on the pullback.

The Swing high plus 15-20 pips would have kept you in the trade with maybe a better chance of a profit before the latest pullback and the Day Engulfing Candle. My guidelines on SL would be 2X ATR7 or Swing High/Low +/- 15pips or so

Looking more at the candle patterns and especially patterns that repeat.  
  
After a strong week, the Friday candle sets HH / HL and a Higher close, which also closes out the week at a recent high  
  
Sunday can either show a small gain or loss, but the Monday candle engulfs Sunday with Tuesday confirming the PA move.  
  
The full chart shows the indicators in play, and if you zoom out again you will see that this price point has been hot as a closing price on 5 occasions, so a pretty good resistance level  
  
The candles on their own tell you a story - adding indicators can reinforce the opinion - some times!!!

Looking for Support and Resistance Levels  
  
Once you have set this up on each chart, it takes a minimal amount of time to maintain - at the end of each week review the chart and see if there is any justification for moving levels / adding new levels.  
  
Chart 1 - start with a blank chart on candlesticks and go to the weekly chart for the pair you are setting up and zoom all the way out - this chart is GU  
  
Chart 2 - switch to Line Chart and look for key prices where you see pull backs / stalls - Use the crosshair to check for multiple price points - the more times the price level is hit, the stronger the S / R level - add Horizontal Lines and depending on your preference, either choose a thicker line or a particular colour for the strongest levels / Historic High / Low. Big Round Numbers (BRNs) also often make for stalling points for PA. 0.5000 1.0000 1.5000 2.0000, etc and often 0.750 1.2500 1.7500, etc The BRNs can be a different colour. At this stage don't put too many lines otherwise everything becomes an s/r level and it will bee too confusing.  
  
Chart 3 - start to zoom in and revert to candlesticks and verify / fine tune your levels. On the weekly chart I will look to put levels at reversals / candlestick closes.  
  
Chart 4 - zoom in one more time and finalize your fine tuning  
  
Chart 5 - switch back to the day chart and you should be set up to show the weekly supprt and resistance levels along with you standard indicators

Introducing ema's into the charts can provide visibility of "Dynamic S and R Levels" as PA hits key emas and bounces away.  
  
The 89ema is often key on the Day chart as is the 200ema  
  
An EMA cross of the 7ema and 23ema can lead to a reversal / trend confirmation  
  
Strong trend runs will often use the 50ema as a dynamic level.  
  
All emas are simple with price = typical hlc/3, shift zero apart from the 7ema which has a shift of 1

Reading indicators and understanding what they are telling you can give you an edge with your trading  
  
All indicators are based off of averages, which means they are all lagging indicators. I have yet to see a leading indicator. Many candle patterns are touted as being high probability reversal signals but you can read PA in accordance with the indicators, regardless of whether it is MACD / Stochastics / Awesome Oscillator, etc.  
  
With this indicator, I would be looking to secure my positions and maybe close all open positions. This is the Bill Williams - Awesome Oscillator and it is saying that PA momentum is drying up. If PA stalls at this level, the indicator will change colour, and if PA then continues the trend, another white bar will be set and this is a good re-entry or add-on signal

Some random thoughts from Big E on trade entries - he was referring to H4 charts for these comments - HA refers to Heikin Ashi - we are using APB, very similar behaviour. These are from the first 5 pages of the [Trading Made Simple](http://www.forexfactory.com/showthread.php?t=291622) forum and well worth going back and re-reading the early days when Big E was active and posting training charts.  
  
TDI was his only indicator although he did start out with Stochastics for confirmation and later dropped them. On the main chart he had a 5EMA with a shift of 1 or 2 to show general PA. So this can be done without all the crap I put on the charts - start simple and see where it takes you.  
  
Hope this helps a few of you in being convinced that the H4 and Day charts offer much less stress and much higher returns for your efforts and to believe that more indicators don't really help ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1) Thanks to Big E - he'll always be remembered on these threads ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f47c.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f647-200d-2642-fe0f.png?v=15.1)  
  
HA candles average a 3-8 candle run in most cases when it reverses... That's why I want to enter on candle 1 or 2 if I see a set up. A single candle on the 4hr nets you 30-60 pips or more generally. If it goes 3-4 candles you've already made 80-150 pips.  
  
  
A set up is NOT GREEN TOUCHING RED. Why? Many times green bounces back and the original direction continues. That's a bounce trade.  
Wait for green to CROSS RED and open your trade at the beginning of the new candle... usually candle 1 or 2.  
Catch the momentum...  
  
**A Normal entry** is when green crosses red on the TDI (and you can actually see the green on the other side)  
**A bounce trade** is when green gets close to red but bounces away and the original trade continues are good entries generally.  
I always look to the left for a possible res/sup level being near. If it's close I pass on the trade and go find another...  
  
I generally quit trading at 6am Pacific (9am est). Why? The market might cook some for the next hour or two but unless there is a hot news announcement during the day... the market pretty much peters out and ranges... I don't want to be trading in that junk. _Thats where dealers make most of your money is ranging markets and 5-15 min time frame trading... you got to quit trading those trash time frames._ Granted there are 2 out of 100 who can Kick bootie there but chances are your in the 98% who can't. I hear it over and over traders complaining that they have 2-3 years experience but can't keep their head above water... always losing or just breaking even... or worse...  
  
_You can't get different results if you keep doing the same thing over and over... just ain't gonna happen anytime soon..._  
  
Years ago I traded stocks but later switched to fx. I started using higher timeframes moving up from 5 to 15 to 30 to 1hr and I was seeing benefits every time I went higher. Kept working on the TDI honeing it to the maximum simplicity possible and moving up to 4hr charts and trading at my bed time... wow what a difference in pips earned... stress free as I slept...

"To live with Passion, it takes Courage and Grace to survive"

I ask because I have been looking at moving more trading to EOD and am just interested in learning others' approaches to daily chart trading. Thanks - {image}

> Ignored

The indicators that help me the most on day charts are the support / resistance levels. The weekly S/R levels are often stall points / reversal points as well as the 200ema which becomes a dynamic S/R level. The Supply / Demand Zones are part of this and they often coincide with the weekly S/R levels.  
  
PA leaving or bouncing off of these is often a strong entry point and in many cases precedes the TDI cross. Moving average crossovers do work for some folks, but are usually read in partnership with other indicators and this adds to the data points in making decisions and often to the analysis paralysis syndrome.  
  
The APB colour change is an additional bonus for an entry as once the colour changes (with a decent candle body and smaller wicks, or a pin bar) the PA will usually follow that direction for several candles.  
  
Waiting until EOD gives you some time to review / analyze the PA relative to the indicators, or the recent candle patterns and in many cases the Asia session can kick off a new move. At the very least, you can create a watch list for pairs more likely to make a move, especially if a TDI cross and/or APB colour change is in play. It will also help to reduce your screen time and the number of trades and therefore stop the overtrading.  
  
Trade durations can be anything from a day to several weeks with a disciplined approach to Stop Loss management and trading the day charts takes out a lot of noise and false signals.  
  
The TDI TSL for me is a very strong indicator - if it is on a trend run from 32 to 68 or 68 to 32, then it is most often telling you that the the momentum has been established and to stay in the trade.  
  
Hope this helps - happy pip hunting

8th day for this trade - AUD CPI went well and PA continues north - next news event for the AUD/NZD pair is the red flag events for RBNZ statements and NZ Trade Balance tomorrow.  
  
Currently the EMA7 and TDi TSL are both trending up, so no real signs for an exit, just keep moving the SL with the PA. PA is back to setting HH / HC / HL, so another good sign for continuation.  
  
200ema now coming into play - if PA breaks through 200ema, the sl will be set to 200ema minus 30.  
  
The Fib is on for those of you who like to see some additional lines ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1) just to show where PA has reached in retracing the 350pips fall from June 4th - to July 10th. A combination of a 61.8 Fib level and the 200ema may well slow things down as may the RBNZ announcements tomorrow.  
  
4th add-on now in play - so what this means is that when the pair stalls / pulls back, for every 1 pip pull back, that is 4 lost pips - this is where you need to stick to the trading plan and manage the SL settings and ensure that combined lost pips do not kill your profits too much. This is all down to risk tolerance for the individual trader - no real set rules here - how many pips can you stand to lose? If this trade continues and fully recovers the prior drop, there is at least another 100pips to go, which equates to an additional 400pips, or if it retraces, it loses 200pips of profit and the end result is +200.  
  
The real test is when it is real money and not a demo account - this is my live account, so real $$$ at stake here.

Full retrace completed

Pivot - Everything should be in Post #1 - the indicator is ATR Pips UL Corner  
  
Short Summary - If ATR7=100pips, then ATR 1 for the APB colour change should be 75pips - however, I would be OK with 50% or 50pips. when the APB changes colour, there needs to be a reasonable body size - not all wicks, so I initially came up with 75% as a test. If you enter on really small candles, the move generally loses momentum. I have attached a snapshot of my data window so you can see it in action.  
  
the APB Guidelines were posted last year and may be of use  
  
_**Indicators for Chart (Day)**_  
Synergy_APB_[C]  
ATR Pips UL Corner – color to none - periods 1 – multiplier 1 - this will give you the ATR for a single candle  
ATR Pips UL Corner – color to none - periods 7 – multiplier 1 (read dcginc posts for using this and setting SL and TP)  
EMA 200 – blue dotted – Price Typical  
EMA 7 - Price typical - shift = 1  
Fractals (Bill Williams)  
Supply and Demand indicator II_SupDem

With all of the Price Action moves in the past 2 weeks - NZD/JPY is worth reviewing  
  
PA was moving higher while TDI was decreasing in strenght, so this gives you a TDI Bearish Divergence warning, which is telling you the next likely PA move is probably down.  
  
There is a very strong APB reversal candle - change of colour and a textbook shape - strong body with wicks top and bottom.  
  
PA breaks and closes below the recent Fractal Low as well as the EMA7.  
  
TDI matches the PA move.  
  
Great angle on the TSL and the EMA7 - While these are in agreement, then there is no reason to exit the trade. Add-ons can be taken as the PA moves lower.  
  
The one hiccup is the pull back which gives a draw down of approx 90 pips, so here is a possible stop out. To mitigate pull backs I try to set my SL to a recent candle close / open - for this example it would mean leaving the SL @ BE for a while longer.  
  
As usual, this is all hindsight training, but a good exercise to get your brain focused on entries and SL settings on longer trade runs.

One of the approaches is to use the ATR7 value. The approach from dcginc was to to set the initial SL to 2XATR7, so depending on the pair and its daily range, that could be 300pips, or swing high / swing low, whichever is the lower value. The worst DD I have seen is 150 - 175 pips. At this time it is usually close to stopping out, so leaving it to run is no real additional risk. The difficult aspect is when PA goes 80 pips down and sits there for 2 days! If you lose the signal / entry criteria completely, then it can be worthwhile to kill the trade and wait for the next set-up - difficult decision.  
  
Typically if the price moves into profit and hits the TP1 level which will be 1XATR7, and then move TP2 to BE, there is a good probability for higher profits - at least worst case is TP1 = 1XATR7 and a TP2 @ BE.

If the Day chart is showing a strong cross, I will take the day signal - I rarely look on the H4 to confirm a Day chart entry. If using the H4 for signals and it goes against a strong Day trend, it is usually a pause in the trend and will then continue with the overall day trend.  
  
This is not a pair that I watch, however, if you use a channel to show the trend, Day and H4 are together, as PA is pulling off of the top of the channel.  
  
Strong hook on the H4 TDI with a corresponding PA off of the channel - it will be interesting to see if the H4 200ema has any effect in holding PA and setting a new support level - Wait for H4 TDI to cross / confirm

Usually I am moving the SL behind each day so using the previous day low or the day before that for a long. IF PA is nearing S/R levels and I see indicators stalling / reversing, I may take a manual exit (and then complain about the additional 100pips I could have got if I stayed in ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1))  
  
One thing that most of the old timers wiil tell you that once an indicator is in the OverSold / OverBought region, they are unreliable, so difficult to use - base all decisions on PA at this point, so if PA starts to reverse and TDI is above 68, consider exiting and saving the pips.  
  
Taking a 2 lot strategy helps to put some early pips in the bank, but using 1 lot for entry and then adding on after the entry ART7 value has been passed will still give very good yields and does reduce your entry risk by 50%.  
  
There will be the occasional loss where both entries get taken out (this will usually occur in the first 3 candles as an Engulfing candle - mostly from a news event, so look ahead at the upcoming news - watch out for for red flag events - I never place trades before NFP and FOMC releases), but I only see this on less than 10% of my trades - the pips won on the bigger trends easily cover that.

Tia,  
  
My rules for day trading are to base all trade decisions off of the previous day close - I review charts during the Asian Sessions, which is 5pm to 8pm Pacific. If there is a strong move in the first 3 hours of the new candle and confirms the previous PA direction, then it can be taken as an entry.  
  
Another strong rule is to trade in the direction of the TDI Trade Signal Line. If the TSL is heading up, ignore any RSI Price Line crosses that are opposite to TSL.  
  
Remember, we are looking for larger pip gains on the day charts - If a pair does not have the possibility of moving 100pips, then we should question whether it is the right pair to trade - there are plenty out there that move 100+pips.

EU weekly is still pushing lower and is heading towards 1.3100 which may hold the PA - no new entries at this time - If PA bounces then there may be more opportunities to enter short once the pause / bounce is done.  
  
From looking at the TDI, here are the observations:  
  
MBL is now below 32 - this does not happen very often with any pair, and may give hope that there will be a pullback in the near future. The MBL will try to pull PA back to the 50% level eventually.  
  
TSL - last 3 days have still seen TSL values dropping and it is now at 24.9 - TSL has only been that low once in the past 3 years. Until TSL starts to increase in values at the day close, ignore any TDI crosses, and then watch out for Supply/Demand Zones and S/R levels.  
  
Once any indicator heads into the Oversold / Overbought zones, they are incredibly difficult to read, so relying on signals from these types of indicators is dangerous.

From Post #1:  
  
**_SL and TP levels:_**  
From the TMS thread - dcginc posted several posts on setting up SL and TP levels using the ATR(7) and I have tweaked this to match my approach.  
  
I now run with 3 entries per set-up and base my SL on the current ATR(7) - usually 1.5XATR(7) or the previous swing H/L / Fractal - this will mean SL levels are sometimes 200 + pips on the more volatile pairs.  
  
TP1 for reversals is 1.5XATR(7)   
  
TP2 - options here are to set TP2 at 3XATR(7), OR, for TP2, you can always leave this open and manually manage the trade. My suggestion is to start out wit the fixed  
  
TP3 - no fixed level - run with manually adjusting SL levels  
  
Experiment with TP1 and TP2, see how it works, modify as necessary, but don't allow the greed glands to take over your trading plan ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f911.png?v=15.1)  
  
Once TP1 is hit, move TP2 and TP3 to B/E and then manage to your trading plan.

I took a few hits during the SNB fallout, as it did spike a few currency pairs.  
  
EUR/AUD closed out on its TS setting (not a result of the SNB actions!), which in hindsight, probably should have been set 50 pips above the 200EMA. That would have been a SL of 250pips on TP3 which would have still protected over 200pips of profit. If this had not been stopped out, then there was an extra 500pips to gain. No tears over spilled milk - this set of trades was still worth a total of 720pips.  
  
Lessons Learned here is that you can open up your SL on the TP3 position and the 200EMA is a Dynamic Zone which is often respected by PA - learn to use it on the day charts.  
  
Next week should be interesting.

with regards to the 233ema, this was a style that Big E was testing with a 23 ema.  
  
I have since reverted to the 200ema and dropped the 23ema.  
  
If price is moving towards the 200ema, you need to have at least the ATR7 value of pips space between PA and the 200ema to make it worthwhile, as PA will often pause / bounce back off the 200ema.  
  
If PA breaks through the 200ema, then consider setting your SL at least 50 pips on the other side of it to give the PA some room to move. See my comments in [post # 2102](http://www.forexfactory.com/showthread.php?p=8002991#post8002991)

> Ignored

Weekly charts take a while to reverse and generate a TDI cross, the weekly will typically lag the day chart by a few days.  
  
For reversals, you could wait for the APB/HA bar to change colour before verifying on the Day chart, but you will miss out on the earlier day chart entries.  
  
I prefer to operate mainly on the day charts and use these to judge the trend - you can still take the weekly charts for setting the S/R levels and these often provide a good signal for reversals. If you have a strong weekly trend, then a day reversal is often a minor pullback/pause before resumption of the trend.  
  
Additionally with the day TDI, entries with the RSI Price line and TSL both heading in the same direction as PA are the stronger entries, especially when they are coming out of the 32 / 68 zones, or the RSI is bouncing off of the TSL, as this gives a better confirmation of the move. Price bounces off of the 200EMA together with a TDI cross are also strong entries. IF the TSL is flat, this is often a sign of price consolidation.

Helanka,  
  
I was creating this post last week so your question is well timed and addresses an issue that many traders struggle with.  
  
_**Risk / Money Management**_  
  
When looking at % of account risk per trade, your initial % at risk can only be calculated once you know your Trade Size, your Stop Loss and your trading account leverage.  
  
For Example:  
  
Account Balance = $1,000  
Trade Size / Lots = 0.05 = $50  
Account Leverage = 100:1  
Stop Loss = 100pips  
  
With the above settings, your Total $ at risk = $50, which means that your % of Account at Risk = 5%  
  
If your Stop Loss is set to 200pips, then your Total $ at risk = $100, which means that the you’re your Account at Risk = 10%. If you are trading with multiple entries, then this amount would be at risk for each trade entered.  
  
The example for using the ATR(7) at trade entry for setting Stop Loss would look like this:  
  
ATR(7) = 120pips  
Stop Loss = 1.5XATR(7) = 180pips  
Account Balance = $1,000  
Trade Size / Lots = 0.05 = $50  
Account Leverage = 100:1  
  
With the above settings, your Total $ at risk = $90, which means that your % of Account at Risk = 9%. If the Account % being risked is too high, reduce the trade size. If you reduce the Stop Loss, all you do is pretty much guarantee that the trade will get stopped out.  
  
The attached spreadsheet may help

With regards to how I select the 8 pairs on my screen - mostly based on the higher ATR7 values - I see no point in watching a pair with an ATR7 of 50 when there are many pairs running at an ATR7 of 100+  
  
I also try to have pairs covering all of the major currencies and due to the Swiss National Bank's policy on the Euro, I had decided not to bother with any of the CHF pairs over a year ago - the EUR and CHF pairs ran pretty close, so I stuck with the EUR pairings.  
  
If one of my 8 drops in volatility and starts to range with a smaller ATR7 then it will be dropped. This happened last year with the UJ so it was dropped. I have another day screen that just has HA on 16 pairs - if I see a colour change then it always worth a look, but the goal is to stick with my 8 selected pairs

Welcome - From what I see on your chart you have the ATR loaded - it's in the top left of your screen. Use your Data Window to see the values.  
  
You have TDI loaded, you can disable the dotted/bolinger lines and just run the TSL / RSI / Market Base Line  
  
You do not show the Synergy APB candles. Check to see if it is installed for the chart.  
  
You have the Fractals loaded - so it looks like you are almost there.  
  
The Il_supdem zones are optional  
  
From post#1  
  
_**Indicators for Chart (Day)**_  
Synergy_APB_[C]  
ATR Pips UL Corner – color to none - periods 1 – multiplier 1 - this will give you the ATR for a single candle  
ATR Pips UL Corner – color to none - periods 7 – multiplier 1 (read dcginc posts for using this and setting SL and TP)  
EMA 200 – blue dotted – Price Typical  
EMA 100 – aqua dotted – Price Typical  
Fractals (Bill Williams)  
Supply and Demand indicator II_SupDem - optional  
  
**_Indicator Window 1_**  
TMSTDI Watchdog – all settings at defaults – Set the alarms that you do not want to false and adjust the font sizes accordingly for your set-up. Colors are personal preference for the TDI lines - I do not use the "Bollinger" lines, so I stick with TSL / RSI and MBL  
Overlay the RSI set to 10 with no color – just a personal preference – higher probability trades when RSI(10) is above 51 for longs and below 49 for shorts. Again – another one for the Data Window.  
  
Fully read Post #1 and follow the links to referenced posts - also read the last two or thee pages - it takes time but will be worth the time spent.

There are two ways fractals are mentioned. The first references HH/LL and usually associated with trailing stops. The second is about support resistance and is usually based on Bill Williams Fractals (SupDemII perhaps being an example).

This is another area where you have to weigh your choices (strong confirmation vs. missed opportunity). You have both the pieces right here: You took the demo trade based on initial candle color, then it changed and went against you. If you wait for confirmation by color on close, you will have missed some pips.  
  
I view TDI cross (or imminent cross) as the foundational trigger. Then the bar color and close outside of PAC as (main) confirmations. Note that PAC is not part of the core methodology in this D thread...I am trying to adapt.  
  
I think it is accurate to say that the TMS expert view is that price action comes first, then TDI. But then you have the discussion about what is good PA which is where some go to candle stick (PA) methods, some to other analysis.  

> [Quoting ZeeDeveel](/thread/post/8032697#post8032697 "View Quoted Post")
> 
> Disliked
> 
> Could we move to a lower timeframe and wait for price to pullback in the opposite direction of the candle's colour for a more precise entry?
> 
> Ignored

Generally, the TMS method is to know the price direction on the next _higher_ timeframe. So if the Weekly TDI Price Line is pointing up, it limits Daily entries to long trades. To fine tune, many look at the next _lower_ TF for a more-precise entry.  
  
It is easy to over-complicate things, so I try to remember that this is Trading Made Simple, not Trading Made Complex.

I have seen people trade with random entry points, but their trade management skills make the overall return favorable. However, I don't know that I am comfortable saying precise entry points are not important. Rather, the more precise your entry _method_ is, the better you can evaluate your results and improve. Same for trade exits.  
  
The way I manage my trades, I _may_ have my stop at BE by the third candle after entry.  
  
The expert traders know that there will be some portion of losses with the best system. So if you enter a trade and take a loss, the evaluation becomes "did I follow my system rules which produce 70% wins over time? If so, (1) nothing was 'wrong' with the trade or (2) there is a possible improvement to my method to increase the winning ratio."  
  
A 70% winning system will have a long string of losses at some point, so you must keep a long-term view.

I've just been doing some rudimentary stats on runs of 7 or more consecutive same coloured bars on 4h timeframe, selected somewhat at random.  
  
These stats wouldn't hold up to too much scrutiny but I would say show some of the signs to look out for:  
  
Long:  
65% of long trades had a small sized candle of the opposite colour preceding it  
47% of the time the first candle of the run was also relatively small (so size of candle seems somewhat irrelevant)  
71% of the time the preceding candle had a longer lower shadow than it's body  
61% the RSI and TSL crossed each other at a sharp angle  
79% the TSL was either parallel or facing upwards  
61% the RSI/TSL cross was below the MBL  
80% of the time the RSI was less than 55%  
  
Short:  
46% of short trades of 7 bars or more were immediately preceded by a fractal (compared with 25% long - this is probably not statistically significant)  
68% of times the preceding candle was of a small size  
50% of the time the first candle of the run was small size (again implying that candle size in either the 1st preceding candle or the 1st candle of the run is of no great importance)  
93% of the time the candle preceding the 7 run short had a upper shadow than it's body  
89% of the time the RSI exceeded 45%  
68% of the time the RSI / TSL crossed at a sharp angle  
86% of the time the cross occurred above the MBL  
39% of the time the RSI and TSL were heading in the same direction (21% less than long)  
  
So there ya have it! Not terribly scientific and wouldn't hold up in a court of law but fairly interesting (to me at least) nonetheless.  
  
Most interestingly was that 71% and 93% respectively, the preceding candle of the run had a very telling shadow.  
86% of big shorts occurred from above the MBL where as 61% of the longs were from below. The longs were also the ones with the 71% revealing shadow on the preceding candle compared to 93% so this implies that the shorts are easier to spot by looking for a crossover above the MBL and a long wick on the preceding candle.  
And it seems that either a sharp crossover or the TSL direction to back up the RSI are important for a good trade.  
Candle size seemed fairly insignificant  
Finally that a low RSI was required for a good long and a high RSI for a good short! 

"Never Take a Trade You Don't Understand!" - Pres78

Here are my last two trades on GPB/JPY  
  
Some overviews on the charts:  
  
The horizontal lines are the weekly S/R levels that coincidentaly line up very closely to 500 pip intervals, so these all become BRNs at 190 / 185 / 175 / 170. Whether this is a self fulfilling prophecy or not? It is interesting on this pair to zoom out and see where PA rolls over and the alignment is there for the past 9 months or so.  
  
The 100/200ema lines also show how these dynamic S/R levels are followed by PA on this pair - 100ema is dominant from 2012, with the 200ema being dominant since Sep 2014.  
  
The zones are manually drawn in and I nuked the Il_supdem indicator only because when PA broke a zone, the indicator removed the zone!  
  
With regards to my day settings for TDI - RSI is set to 3, TSL is set to 8.  
  
I tend not to bother with the RSI 10 values so have removed it.  
  
My golden rule for watching pairs on the day charts - If the HA / APB changes colour (depending on which you use, I am using HA but I am not convinced there is much difference in how this affects my trading!), then it is worth looking at as the "trigger candle" for a possible entry.  
  
If the RSI has crossed the TSL at day close AND the TSL is moving in the same direction as the PA (proposed trade), then this is a higher probability entry. If you want to verify of the TSL is increasing or decreasing in value, then enable the TDI Visualization to "show in the data window"  
  
Commentary on the 2 entries.  
  
Entry 1 - traditional TDI cross:  
PA had hit the 185.00 and stalled and was now moving lower. Change in colour on HA, so this becomes my trigger candle. TDI cross with TSL heading down. 3 entries taken - first entry closed at +128 and SL moved (too aggressive) and was hit by the pull back for +5 pips. Hindsight - could have left this alone for another day before closing and moving SL.  
  
Entry 2 - continuation of trend - no TDI cross - PA break of 100ema and weekly S/R level:  
PA approaching 180.00 and has broken 100ema with 300pips clearance to 200ema, so this becomes my trigger candle. TSL and RSI still heading lower - entries set from 180.10 to 179.90 (probably should have set all entries below 180.00!). First position closed before Friday close and SL moved just above Friday open - if PA pulls back then worst case is BE on all 3 entries. Will monitor Sunday opening and move SL if PA continues south.

Richard - sounds like a good plan - my biggest issue was over trading until I settled on the day charts - it's a very common issue. Next up on the list was entering too early and not waiting for the signals to confirm PA and TDI direction (or even worse, dropping down in time frames and taking the H4 signals!) - I used to try and get every pip on a move, but once you realize there are hundreds of pips on the the day charts major moves, then missing 150pips is not a concern.  
  
Having a core number of pairs to watch works well for me as you get accustomed to how they move and how they interact with weekly S/R levels and the 100/200ema.  
  
I only ever take a set up after day close and try to place any new trade entries in the first few hours of the new day candle, or, worst case, no later than 8pm Pacific. If I miss the move - too bad - I will not place a trade until after the next day close, or until the next S/R break / bounce, or TDI cross / bounce.

Currently I enter with 3 entries as individual trades about 5 pips apart. This means I can close them manually one at a time and with the stupid USA broker rules for FIFO this does work. I am looking to run TP1 and then move to BE after that triggers, for TP2 and TP3, run the SL to the previous candle low - this would result in both being stopped out on April 3rd pull back. Any trade resulting in profit is a good thing - closing too early sometimes leaves you regretting it because that can "lose" several hundred pips. I have done this many times as the temptation is to bank the $ with the live accounts ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1). It's all a case of fine tuning once the entry signals are clear.  
  
The trend reversals only occur every couple of weeks or so, so this means that depending on how many pairs you trade, you may see a trade entry opportunity most weeks. Mostly I am seeing 3 or 4 trade entries per month, with the possibility of several hundred pips per trade if I actually stick to my trade plan ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f61e.png?v=15.1), but then I am focusing on a lower number of pairs.

To get a feel for how this works with waiting for the TSL to move in the same direction as the proposed trade, expand your indicator window 1 to full screen and add a vertical line for TDI crosses where both RSI and TSL have crossed and are moving in the same direction. Then pull the window back down and see what this would have yielded with regards to the # of pips won / lost.  
  
Next step is run through some manual back tests and use the F12 button and advance one candle at a time - when you see a cross that is valid, mark with the vertical line. Rinse, repeat and see how this approach works.

Just saw the following re-posted on the TMS thread which was a post from Big E as he was teaching on what he looks for before each entry - worth re-posting here  
  
_**_Your safest trades will always be when green crosses red and you enter on candle 1 or 2... odds are in your favor._**_ Why? Because I'm expecting 3-8 candles... which is average...  
  
With bounce trades the odds are lower for your success... but it still works.  
  
**__When wanting to enter a TDI trade... take a moment first to observe basic 4x things... like:__**  
  
How close am I to the previous high or lo _(for the day charts this will be the weekly S/R levels)_  
  
Am I in an uptrend or downtrend.. short & long term... (for the day charts, we are usually looking for reversals or trend continuations after a pause)  
  
Am I in or close to a consolidation area  
  
Are the previous candles small...  
  
Look at the candles on the last reversal... big, little, what  
  
How does the momentum look right now (12-2, 4-6) _(referring to the TDI momentum with regards to a clock face)_  
  
Does Stoch's confirm the TDI signal - I am not using stochastics, _(__this was part of Big E's original method, but he stopped using it.)_  
  
Sounds like a lot of stuff but it's basic stuff and only takes a moment to observe it...  
  
If you don't already know these things... don't trade live yet... [www.babypips.com](http://www.babypips.com/) is a good place to learn about the basics of trading 4X.  
  
[http://www.forexfactory.com/showthre...40#post4581540](http://www.forexfactory.com/showthread.php?p=4581540#post4581540)

If you can crack this problem, you get the keys to the kingdom ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
I typically place my SL at the bottom of the previous candle for long trades after TP1 is hit (1xATR7), so the main issue here is when the price spikes beyond the ATR 7 value.  
  
Mostly it will depend on your risk tolerance as to how many pips you are willing to sacrifice in the hope of getting the large trend runs, so you can always test out the theory of using a trailing stop of 1.5 x atr 7 on the day candle, but that can be 300+ pips sacrificed on TP2 and TP3.  
  
In the attached chart, pa gets to a profit of 480 pips, but with the SL at the bottom of the APB candle, this gives up 260pips on each of TP2 and TP3, so the combined profit for each of the entries would have been 410 pips out of a possible 1,000 pips.  
  
Not sure there is a scientific response to your question - I too suffer from this on the longer term trends. In the end I take the hits and look for re-entries from a new cross or TDI bounce.

Just my 2 cents here but here's how I do it. 03 trades opened at same price with pending orders( buy/sell stop). First profit taken when price is equal to the size of the trigger candle(set and forget), second profit taken when present tdi hooks or crosses( individual preference), let the third trade run till the htf tdi changes direction. On the daily tf the third trade sometimes goes on for more than a month with huge pips. I am not in the position,but someone trading full lots would need a pick-up, wheelbarrow wouldn't suffice.

Here's the current template for the TDI settings for RSI = 3 and TSL = 8 for use on day charts as well as the custom indicators (these need to be installed before adding the template). This is with the Synergy APB - if you prefer Heikin Ashi, just delete the APB and add the HA instead.  
  
Indicators:  
  
Main Chart  
Bill Williams Fractals  
Average Price Bars (APB) - these can be edited  
100ema moving average  
200ema moving average  
7 linear weighted - shift = 1, weighted close HLCC/4  
ATR pips ul corner  
  
Indicator window 1  
@TMSTDI Watchdog

Hey hsn,  
  
I'm also watching this pair, I'm waiting on the next candle because I want to see a strong candle away from the 100ma and then I will go short, also I personally dont enter a trade on a Sunday night, like to leave the markets alone for 24H after the weekend just to let things get settled. Its a good strong cross and will enter looking for a new low for T2 if a strong bear candle is produced on Monday showing the 100ma has no strength, but look left, sitting on bits of support so I want a strong candle.   
  
Im no expert but from my experience of using this method you just need to be patient and take only the best signals, do not over trade taking every cross. My average over the past 6 months is only 8 trades per month consisting of 2 losses, 3b/e and 3 winning, works for me with 3x1RR.   
  
Good luck man/woman

Hi Profanans,  
  
I am also a german guy, so I also wait till it's 5 min before 11PM, I then look at the Charts if there is an valid signal an then at 11PM and 2 min I will take the trade or not.  
At Friday I won't take a trade, I will look Sunday at market open if there is a valid Signal.  
  
A tip from a good german trader is first test this system with a simulator for 20-30 min on a day for around 2 months, then change to demo for another half year.  
  
regards

Hi Catalin,  
  
some times the price will go any further south wenn you are at 32 at the TDI but be careful. I'm trying to not trade in these areas.  
What you can make is to avaible the volatility-bands on the TDI. I think the best trades will come when price were outside the bands and come back. Also when Short-Setup comes near/over the 68 and Long near/under the 32.  
  
When you look on your example on EURJPY you will see that TDI works flat/range on the last 10 candles roundabout, avoid this and look for a better Setup.  
In october this year I've found only 3-4 Setups, on Daily we have to be patient and have to wait for the best Setups(also on other TFs). Thats also a problem for me as you can see in the EURGBP above.  
  
regards  
  
Thorsten

Guys the problem we have here is wanting ti capture the entire spike that results out of the news release. I trade news quite differently with a fairly high level of success. For me it is not how many pips you make but how much dollars you make. Let me share with you three trades I took this month

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: GBPUSDM5.png
Size: 42 KB](/attachment/image/1793858/thumbnail?d=1447683937)](/attachment/image/1793858?d=1447683937)   

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: EURUSDM5.png
Size: 46 KB](/attachment/image/1793861/thumbnail?d=1447683992)](/attachment/image/1793861?d=1447683992)   

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: AUDUSDM5.png
Size: 43 KB](/attachment/image/1793862/thumbnail?d=1447684024)](/attachment/image/1793862?d=1447684024)   

  
  
These are M5 charts. I base my trades on M5 charts after the release. I aim for 40% of the candle body excluding the tail/ wick. That is if the candle body is 60 pips my take profit is 60 x 0.4 = 24 pips + spread. And I do not trade every news release.  
  
Out of the three trades, the AUD one did not get to mt tp but I exited with more than half my intended target.  
  
With experience the strike rate could be around 75%
